In our wide-ranging discussion, I made clear to General Mattis that the next Secretary of Defense must recognize and preserve the critical contributions of the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard and the Pease Air National Guard Base. General Mattis has served our country with distinction and I very much appreciated his many insights on how best to strengthen our defense capabilities and respond to our adversaries. I look forward to discussing these issues in greater depth during his confirmation hearing." --J.S.  Senator Shaheen is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

This is what Senator Shaheen had to say today after Republican leadership announced plans to defund Planned Parenthood through budget reconciliation legislation that would also repeal healthcare reform:  "Republican leaders in Congress do not have a mandate to defund Planned Parenthood. The American people want to see their elected leaders working together to expand healthcare opportunities, not undermining vital healthcare coverage that women in New Hampshire and across the country depend on. Defunding Planned Parenthood would leave thousands of women and families in New Hampshire without access to vital preventative care services that they need in order to live healthy lives, care for their families, and lead in the workforce. This is a dangerous, politically-motivated attack on women and I will not stand for it."-- J.S.

Earlier today, Senator Shaheen questioned General Mattis (President-elect Trump's pick to serve as Secretary of Defense). Shaheen questioned Gen. Gen. Mattis replied that NATO “is the most successful military alliance in modern world history” and that it is in the United States’ best interest to “maintain the strongest possible relationship with NATO.” Shaheen pressed Gen. Mattis on President-elect Trump’s many statements with respect to continued support for U.S. allies and whether President-elect Trump recognizes the value of NATO, to which Gen. Mattis responded that “he understands where I stand.”  During their exchange, Shaheen also asked him about the importance of National Guard readiness, highlighting the challenges that the New Hampshire National Guard faces with resources, training rotations, equipment and other aspects of readiness. “We have to keep the National Guard and the reserves of all the armed forces at the top of their game,” Gen. Mattis replied, noting that “as an operational reserve and strategic reserve [the National Guard] will be critical.” Shaheen also highlighted previous comments made by Gen. Mattis on whether he will “continue to support the military’s effort to pursue alternative and more efficient sources of energy to reduce our reliance on conventional fuel supplies.” Gen. Mattis replied that they will “take advantage of every advance in terms… extending our energy efforts.”

It was announced today that Senator Shaheen will serve as the lead Democrat on the Commerce, Justice, Science Appropriations Subcommittee. This panel is tasked with authoring the annual funding bill for the Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), Department of Commerce, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), National Science Foundation, and other agencies.  “It will be an honor to advocate for fiscal responsibility and champion New Hampshire priorities on this important subcommittee,” said Shaheen after the announcement was made. “As vice chair, I look forward to reviewing these programs line by line to see where we can save taxpayer dollars. Among my other top priorities will be to support programs that help local law enforcement, monitor and combat climate change, invest in life-saving research, protect New Hampshire’s fishing industry, and promote New Hampshire’s small businesses.”

As President-elect Trump & Republican leaders move forward with Affordable Care Act repeal, Senators Jeanne Shaheen & Maggie Hassan heard the concerns of New Hampshire healthcare providers & policy leaders at roundtable discussion in Manchester today. Experts testified on the disproportional impact that ACA repeal would have on low- and middle-income families in New Hampshire. They also drew attention to the expanded coverage provided for mental health and substance misuse treatment, which has been vital as the state combats the opioid epidemic, as well as for the management of diabetes and other diseases. Providers also highlighted the harmful effects of repeal, which hospital administrators have already factored into investments for the future of their practices. Repealing the ACA and the corresponding compensation structure would disrupt hospitals and healthcare providers’ ability to plan ahead.  Just following the round table discussion, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) released a report on the Republicans’ plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act. The report estimated that by repealing the ACA without a replacement, 32 million people would lose healthcare coverage by 2026, with nearly 18 million Americans losing coverage in the first year of enactment. Premiums in individual markets would about double by 2026.  This is what Senator Shaheen had to say about today's events: "The message from these New Hampshire healthcare experts is clear: the ACA has made our state healthier and a wholesale repeal would be devastating for all those Granite Staters who have coverage thanks to the law. Today’s CBO report underscores the recklessness of Republican leadership and President-elect Trump’s efforts to repeal this law, especially with no prepared replacement. Nearly 1 out of every 10 Granite Staters rely on coverage afforded by the ACA for vital preventative health services like cancer screenings, blood pressure monitoring and contraceptives, and many other healthcare services that are critical to long-term health and wellbeing. I will continue to encourage President-elect Trump and Republican leadership in Congress to work across the aisle to improve this law, rather than risk unnecessary chaos and uncertainty in the lives of millions of American families."

This is what Senator Shaheen had to say after President Trump reinstated the Global Gag Rule, also known as the Mexico City Policy, which bans federal funds for non-governmental organizations that provide abortion services or provide information about abortion as part of family planning services:   "The Trump Administration and Republican leadership have made no secret of their dangerous obsession with rolling back reproductive rights. President Trump's reinstatement of the Global Gag Rule ignores decades of research, instead favoring ideological politics over women and families. We know that when family planning services and contraceptives are easily accessible, there are fewer unplanned pregnancies, maternal deaths, and abortions. And when women have control over their reproductive health, it improves the long-term health of mothers and children and creates a lasting economic benefit. I will continue to stand up to President Trump and Republican leadership in Congress who are intent on rolling back women's access to reproductive healthcare, and will introduce bipartisan legislation to repeal the Global Gag Rule for good." --J.S.

“After careful consideration, I could not support Rex Tillerson’s nomination to serve as Secretary of State. Mr. Tillerson’s willingness to serve is very admirable, and I appreciate his commitment to the Transatlantic Alliance and NATO, as well as his strong support for programs that empower women and girls around the world. However, I was troubled by his non-committal responses on the importance of supporting reproductive health and family planning, imposing further sanctions on Russia, calling out violations of human rights and addressing climate change. In the end, I simply have too many concerns and outstanding questions about his positions to vote to confirm him.” --J.S.

Today I introduced the bipartisan Global HER Act to permanently repeal the Global Gag Rule that President Trump not only reinstated, but also dramatically expanded yesterday. Previously, this policy applied only to family planning funding. But under President Trump, it applies to every program that falls under global health assistance. This means that it puts at risk 15 times more funding, and millions more women and families.This targets some of the most effective health organizations at work in the developing world. Without funding, these organizations won’t be able to provide HIV services and maternal healthcare, or counsel women on the risks of Zika infection.   So far my legislation has the backing of 47 Senators and 129 Representatives in the House. President Trump's executive order is extremely short sighted and shows his willingness to ignore decades of research in favor of ideological politics. I am proud to have bipartisan support for my legislation to repeal the Global Gag Rule for good. We know that the way to decrease unplanned pregnancies and abortions is to make birth control and family planning services accessible and affordable, not micromanage the type of medical information and reproductive health counseling that women around the world receive. The Global HER Act would ensure that clinics don’t have to choose between providing comprehensive family planning services to a smaller group of women on a limited budget or providing limited reproductive health services with U.S. funds. -- J.S.

In 2007, under the direction of then-President George W. Bush, the Department of Justice concluded a five year voter fraud investigation that found hardly any instances of voter fraud among all the ballots cast across the country. Of the few examples of fraudulent ballots, the majority were simply the result of mistakenly filled out registration forms or misunderstood eligibility rules. President Trump won the election and he needs to move on. It’s a total waste of taxpayer dollars to launch an investigation with no evidence of fraud. Their deaths should forever serve as a warning to the catastrophic consequences of hatred and intolerance. It’s on us to fight back every day against those who would divide us. --J.S.

The immigration executive order that President Trump signed yesterday is un-American and grossly inhumane. We are a nation of immigrants and should remain welcoming to all nations and faiths, particularly those who are fleeing violence and oppression. Refugees, from Syria in particular, are fleeing unspeakable terror and hunger, and it’s unconscionable that the United States will no longer provide any of these refugees a safe haven.   This order also endangers our troops and diplomats. Discriminating based on religion and nationality severely undermines the local alliances and trust established by our troops and diplomats in the field. This order is so ill-considered that it is even barring Iraqi civilians who have provided essential assistance to the U.S. mission. We owe a tremendous debt to the brave Iraqis who have stood shoulder-to-shoulder with Americans in the field, putting themselves and their families at risk to help our soldiers and diplomats accomplish their mission and return home safely. To abandon them now would be a stain on our national honor. --J.S.

As a parent, a former public school teacher, a governor and a senator, I’ve always cared deeply about providing equal opportunity for our children. I was dismayed by many of Ms. DeVos’s answers during her confirmation hearing. Her answer to Senator Hassan’s questioning on this subject was entirely unacceptable. Throughout her confirmation hearing, she did not express a real commitment to our nation’s public schools which are the best opportunity for kids from all walks of life to get the education they deserve. I cannot in good conscience support her nomination and will also strongly urge my colleagues to oppose her nomination. --J.S.

In yesterday's Portsmouth Herald, Granite Staters covered by the Affordable Care Act express their concerns about their healthcare as President Trump and Republican leaders in Congress move forward with repeal. It's highly reckless to threaten repeal without a replacement plan. This law isn't perfect, but there's no doubt that it has made New Hampshire healthier and helped in the fight against the opioid epidemic. This is why I'm committed to working across the aisle to improve the law to expand coverage and affordability. I will fight against partisan attempts to take us back to the days of discrimination based on pre-existing conditions and higher numbers of uninsured in New Hampshire. --J.S.   http://www.seacoastonline.com/news/20170226/granite-staters-covered-by-obamacare-fear-repeal-repercussions

It was great meeting with General Milley, the Chief of Staff of the Army, at the Manchester Armory this past weekend. A fellow New Englander, General Milley discussed the importance of the Army National Guard’s readiness in roundtable discussions. We owe the men and women of our National Guard the most advanced equipment and training, and I will continue to prioritize resources for additional training rotations on the Armed Services Committee.

US News just ranked New Hampshire as number two in the nation in their Best States rankings.  In my opinion, we should be first but I’ll take it!  In the US News ranking, our state ranks first in economic opportunity and third in education.  I’m very proud of our state’s progress and will continue working hard in the Senate for all Granite Staters. – J.S.

The surge in hate crimes across the country should spur an aggressive response from the federal government, particularly from the Department of Justice.  These crimes are reprehensible and un-American. The Trump administration must demonstrate with real action that it stands with religious and racial minorities against hate. The weak response we’ve seen thus far from the Trump administration is unacceptable. – J.S.

The Violence Against Women Act is a proven tool in supporting victims of domestic violence, social service providers and law enforcement officials.  It is more important than ever that we stand with women, and the services afforded through VAWA have an enormous impact.  I joined several of my colleagues in urging the Trump administration to support and fund the programs established by VAWA.

Jennifer Frizzell of Planned Parenthood of Northern New England is my guest for tonight's speech by President Trump to a joint session of Congress. She's representing the women in NH who depend on #PlannedParenthood for reproductive and preventative care.

This evening, President Trump addressed many issues important to Granite Staters and I am committed to working across the aisle on areas of common ground such as combatting the opioid epidemic, rebuilding our infrastructure, providing paid family leave, and lowering the cost of prescription drugs. However, I'm disappointed that many of his promises were significantly undermined by the policies he put forward.  It’s time for President Trump and Republican leadership in Congress to move on from their reckless threats of repealing the Affordable Care Act and begin discussions about how we can work across the aisle to improve the law, lower costs and expand coverage. The healthcare proposals put forward by President Trump this evening will reduce coverage and affordability for thousands of Granite Staters.  In his speech, President Trump again promised to expand substance misuse treatment just one day after proposing a budget outline that would force severe cuts to domestic programs that are critical to supporting New Hampshire's efforts to combat the opioid epidemic.​ Doubling down on repeal of the Affordable Care Act and the drastic cuts to the Medicaid program ‎he promised will negate the progress we have made, setting us back in the fight against drug misuse. Once again, the policies put forward by President Trump don't line up with his promises.  I was also troubled that the President passed up another opportunity to send a truly unifying message to the American people. It's disheartening to again hear him advocate for his un-American Muslim ban executive order and malign immigrants who continue to enrich the fabric of our nation. --J.S.
President Trump's delay of his reworked #MuslimBan for press coverage proves that his Executive Order is about politics and not security.  It's time to scrap this ban entirely.

Meet Ilyssa of Rollinsford and Carla of Newfields, who I met in the U.S. Capitol this afternoon. Ilyssa and Carla are in Washington today with other Granite Staters to speak up for Planned Parenthood and the critical health care services that Planned Parenthood clinics in NH provide. Planned Parenthood was there for Ilyssa and Carla when they needed it most. - JS

Earlier today I spoke on the Senate floor against President Trump and Republican leadership’s efforts to discriminate against Title X family planning providers, including Planned Parenthood. For years now, Republican leaders in Congress have attempted to defund this essential healthcare provider, which serves millions of women nationwide, including nearly 12,000 women in my State, most of them with incomes below or near the poverty line. The sad irony of these attacks on Planned Parenthood is that study after study has shown that cutting back access to birth control and other family planning methods actually increases the number of abortions. The good news is that, according to poll after poll, the American people – across the political spectrum –strongly support Planned Parenthood and oppose efforts to defund it. – J.S.

I just voted NO on Dr. Ben Carson's nomination to serve as secretary of Housing and Urban Development. While I respect Dr. Carson’s willingness to serve, I do not have confidence that he has the necessary experience or expertise. The department needs a leader who on day one can take the reins and manage programs that protect fair housing policies, provide low-income families with affordable housing, and promote the development of transitional housing for those in recovery from substance misuse. --J.S.

In his joint address to Congress on Tuesday, President Trump once again promised to expand treatment and end the opioid crisis. He made the same promise in campaign events in New Hampshire last year. Today, I sent a letter to President Trump expressing my very real concern about his policies that, instead of helping New Hampshire fight the opioid epidemic, would severely undermine our efforts. His budget would drastically cut many programs that treatment providers and first responders rely on. Repealing the Affordable Care Act and cutting Medicaid would take away substance misuse treatment from those who desperately need it. New Hampshire can’t afford empty promises. I am urging the President to follow through on his commitment to expand treatment, so we can turn the tide of this epidemic. — JS

I voted NO on Gov. Rick Perry's nomination to serve as Secretary of Energy. The United States is a global leader on energy efficiency, employing nearly 2 million Americans in the clean energy sector and driving policies to protect our climate. I cannot in good conscience support the confirmation of Gov. Perry to an Administration that has put a bullseye on the Energy Department’s critical work on climate research, and the development of energy efficiency and clean energy technologies that create jobs and boost our economy. We need an Energy Secretary who is committed to advancing technologies that will ensure our businesses and manufactures remain globally competitive and on the cutting edge. Unfortunately, it’s clear the Trump Administration doesn’t share this view. – J.S.

President Trump is recklessly pursuing a campaign promise at the expense of fundamental American values and our safety. The Trump administration's decision to delay this revised ban in order to maximize positive press coverage sends a clear message that this directive is about politics, not national security. Arbitrarily imposing travel restrictions on certain Muslim-majority countries only makes us less safe by reinforcing terrorist propaganda and recruitment. It's shameful that this administration would needlessly separate families and single out refugees who are fleeing violence and seeking a better life. Immigrants make up the fabric of this country, and they continue to enrich our communities and strengthen our economy. America is better than this. – J.S.

Today in Manchester, I met with Tamam Mohamad, his wife Wedyan, and his daughter Talah. Tamam came to our country from Iraq in 1999 with only $20 in his pocket. After becoming a U.S. citizen, Tamam wanted to give back to this country so he went back to Iraq to serve as an interpreter for U.S. military forces for three years. Upon his return to New Hampshire in 2010, Tamam opened Spice Center, the popular Arab and Middle Eastern market in Manchester. All of Tamam’s employees at Spice Center are immigrants, many of them from Iraq. Tamam’s story is just one example of the many contributions that immigrants make to New Hampshire and our great country.

Yesterday, I sent a bipartisan letter to President Trump, along with a handful of my Senate colleagues, expressing our opposition to his reinstatement and expansion of the Mexico City Policy. President Trump’s drastically expanded policy takes aim at family planning services and could ultimately affect some of the most successful global health programs around the world, including our PEPFAR program that provides HIV/AIDS relief and has enabled two million children to be born HIV-free to infected mothers. We asked President Trump to clarify how this action will impact our efforts to save the lives of women and children who are dying from preventable causes. And we urge the Trump Administration to work with Congress to ensure that U.S. investments in global health are effective, efficient, and contribute to a more secure world for the United States.

The Affordable Care Act repeal bill just announced by House Republican leadership would be nothing short of a disaster for healthcare coverage in New Hampshire and a devastating blow to our efforts to combat the opioid epidemic. This is clearly a broken promise by President Trump and Republican leadership who assured the American public that nobody would be kicked off of their healthcare coverage. It’s unconscionable that this bill would decimate the Medicaid program and eliminate healthcare subsidies for the middle class while the wealthy get another tax break and insurance company CEOs get a pay bump. The bill also defunds Planned Parenthood, jeopardizing vital preventative and reproductive care for thousands of women in New Hampshire. It took Republican leadership seven years to come up with this repeal bill.  This proposal clearly demonstrates why Republican leadership should keep the Affordable Care Act and finally commit to working across the aisle to improve it. – J.S.

ICYMI: Last night I spoke with Erin Burnett about my concerns regarding Russian interference in our election. Beyond Attorney General Session’s testimony, the fundamental question is what ties exist between Russia and the Trump campaign. It’s critical that there be an independent investigation. I also spoke on the Trump administration’s revised #MuslimBan, which is un-American and makes our country less safe. Immigrants make up the fabric of this country, and they continue to enrich our communities and strengthen our economy.

It’s shameful that that the Trump administration is considering separating children from their parents at the border. This would be grossly inhumane. Tearing apart families endangers the health and safety of children, who have had no choice in their arrival to our country. I’m urging DHS to not move forward with this terrible proposal. America is better than this. -- J.S.

News reports of an online group of Marines sharing explicit photos of women Marines are very disturbing. The sexual harassment these women have endured is totally unacceptable. The perpetrators' actions undermine morale and dishonor the proud history of the U.S. Marine Corps. It is important that the Pentagon thoroughly investigate the matter, and I expect to hear more from military leadership about how it plans to punish those responsible for this gross misconduct and how it plans to prevent future harassment. The women of the Marine Corps serve with honor and dignity, and deserve the same respect their male counterparts receive. -- J.S.
I'm wearing red today in solidarity with women everywhere. On International Women's Day, it's important we recognize that women and girls have the power to transform our world. -- J.S.

For International Women’s Day, I spoke with Elle Magazine about the importance of empowering women across the globe. I touched on four major challenges facing women and girls today: family planning, education, gender-based violence, and representation in government. All of these issues are interconnected and have a major role in establishing gender equality, lifting women out of poverty and improving the health and safety of our communities around the world. When women and girls have access to an education and critical healthcare, including family planning, this unleashes their ability to participate equally in their communities, in the workplace, and in the political arena. – J.S.

Some of the women on my staff joined me in wearing red to the Senate today to commemorate International Women’s Day and the incredible contributions that women make to our society, our economy and our world.   Tonight, the Senate passed my bipartisan resolution commemorating International Women’s Day and recommitting to the fight to advance equality and empowerment of women all across the globe. In January, millions of women marched in cities around the world and our message was loud and clear:  We will not allow our reproductive rights and other human rights to be taken away.  We will not allow women to be targeted for discrimination.  We will not be taken backward.  On this International Women’s Day, we rededicate ourselves to achieving respect, equality, and justice for women in every community and every country across the globe. – J.S.

Last night I spoke on the Senate floor as part of a bipartisan call to impose further sanctions on Russia. Today, we face new and unprecedented threats from an increasingly aggressive Russia. Russia continues to illegally occupy territory in Georgia and the Ukraine. It is building up its military presence and making threatening moves in the Balkans. There is clear evidence that Russia is actively interfering in elections in France, Germany, and across Europe. But most brazenly, Russia has used cyberattacks and other measures to aggressively interfere in our presidential election. We must demonstrate to President Putin that this type of behavior will not be tolerated. Interfering in our elections strikes at the democratic foundation of this country and we cannot allow this to go unpunished. – J.S.

I’ve been reading the bill that House Republican leadership and President Trump released this week to repeal the Affordable Care Act (also known as Obamacare) and I’ve got to tell you, it’s a total disaster. Despite their many promises to the contrary, President Trump and House Republicans are pushing a bill that would severely undermine healthcare coverage for millions of Americans. It would also be a devastating blow to our efforts to combat the opioid epidemic. On top of taking health insurance away from millions of Americans, the House Republican plan decimates the Medicaid program, increases premiums for seniors and older Americans, forces the middle class to pay more for less, and defunds vital preventative and reproductive care for women.    Mind you, not everyone is hurt by this bill: Insurance company CEOs get a special tax break. That’s right, hidden in the Republican health care bill is a special tax break that allows Health Care companies to write off CEO pay over $500,000 a year. What’s more outrageous is that this tax break for CEOs is paid for by charging senior citizens an additional $7,000 a year for health care. This bill is a tax giveaway to the wealthy, masquerading as health care reform. It’s shameful.  In dozens of visits to New Hampshire during the campaign, President Trump promised to provide treatment to end the opioid crisis. So why is he pushing for healthcare repeal and many other policies that would take away substance misuse treatment and many other resources that New Hampshire desperately needs to fight the drug epidemic? That’s exactly the question I put to him in a letter last week. In it, I call on the President to keep his promise to communities across New Hampshire that are fighting this epidemic with everything they have. I’ll keep you updated and let you know if President Trump responds.   As I’ve said many times, the Affordable Care Act isn’t perfect, but it has undoubtedly made New Hampshire healthier and has helped expand substance misuse treatment coverage to those who desperately need it. In New Hampshire, the uninsured rate has dropped by 43%. A big part of that reduction comes from the coverage provided through Medicaid expansion. Instead of repealing this progress, House Republicans should be working across the aisle to improve the Affordable Care Act. In the last congress, I successfully improved the law to help small businesses. I’ve proven that bipartisan progress on healthcare is possible. This is the much better route for the health, well-being, and peace of mind of Granite Staters. I’m strongly against this reckless repeal bill and I’ll be urging my colleagues in the Senate to oppose it. - J.S.

I spoke on the Senate floor yesterday in opposition to President Trump and Republican leadership’s bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. I’ve spoken with so many Granite Staters whose lives have been saved thanks to Obamacare and Medicaid Expansion. For them, repealing Obamacare isn’t about politics, it’s about life and death. Trumpcare, on the other hand, would have catastrophic consequences in New Hampshire and our efforts to combat the opioid epidemic. I shared several stories from Granite Staters whose lives would be disrupted if Obamacare is repealed. Republicans in Congress should work with us to make fixes to Obamacare, not repeal it altogether. Please continue to send me your stories at HowACAHelpedMe@Shaheen.Senate.gov so I can show my colleagues just how important this is to our state. – J.S.

In honor of Women’s History Month, I want to share someone who has inspired me since my early years in New Hampshire politics. Marilla Ricker of New Durham was a woman before her time. Marilla was the first woman to be accepted into the bar in New Hampshire, the first woman to run for governor, and the first woman to apply for a foreign ambassadorship post. For five decades, she attempted to cast a ballot in our elections and was denied because she was a woman. She died in 1920 shortly after women won the right to vote. Marilla’s fight for women’s equality lives on today as women march in the streets for equal rights, their message loud and clear: we won’t go back. – J.S.
It was a honor to attend the New Hampshire Army National Guard Welcome Home Ceremony today and thank the 197th Field Artillery Brigade for their service. New Hampshire is proud and grateful.-- J.S.

This morning, Senator Hassan and I are speaking out against President Trump and Republican Leadership’s bill that repeals the Affordable Care Act. Alongside Granite State healthcare and treatment providers, we’ll discuss the devastating impact that Trumpcare would have on our state. You can watch the livestream here: http://www.nh1.com/live-streaming/

Earlier this month I had the opportunity to meet Carla of Newfields and hear firsthand how Planned Parenthood provided her with compassionate, dependable care. One in five American women will visit a Planned Parenthood health center at least once in her life, and Carla represents the millions of women who depend on Planned Parenthood for basic primary and preventative health services, including life-saving cancer screenings, pap tests, breast exams, birth control, and HIV testing. Defunding Planned Parenthood would leave millions of women like Carla without access to these vital preventative care services that they need in order to live healthy lives, care for their families, and lead in the workforce. Carla knows what’s at stake for women, and I promise to stand with her and fight to protect women’s constitutionally protected right to make our own reproductive choices. – J.S.

I want to thank Ellie for her courage in sharing her story about dealing with mental illness. As a country we simply must do better when it comes to increasing access to mental health services, particularly for children and young adults. We must also do more to help diminish the stigma that sadly prevents too many from seeking the treatment they need. Treatment makes a difference for people like Ellie, and it’s our responsibility to support her and others affected by mental illness. Thank you to Ellie and Change Direction NH for bringing greater awareness to this important issue. – J.S.

This morning Sen. Maggie Hassan and I spoke out against Trumpcare and the devastating effect it would have on the Granite State. We also heard from Brendan Williams, President and CEO of the NH Health Care Association, Robert Steigmeyer, President and CEO of Concord Hospital, and Philip Spagnuolo, a Granite Stater who relied on Medicaid for substance use treatment and is now a licensed recovery coach. For people like Phil, Medicaid has been critical. But Trumpcare phases-out Medicaid expansion and makes private healthcare coverage unaffordable, which means less drug treatment care when New Hampshire can least afford it. This reckless bill also dramatically increases costs for seniors and older Americans and defunds Planned Parenthood, taking away vital preventative and reproductive care for women. The bottom line is Trumpcare will result in higher healthcare costs and less coverage. Instead of moving forward with this disastrous bill, we should work across the aisle to improve the Affordable Care Act. – J.S.

Yesterday, the Congressional Budget Office released their nonpartisan report on Trumpcare, and it confirms our worst fears about the catastrophic impact of this bill. President Trump and Republican leadership do not have a mandate to throw 24 million Americans off of their healthcare. Trumpcare would result in higher healthcare costs and less coverage which will be devastating for Granite Staters. It would also roll back the progress we have made in combating the opioid epidemic. I’ll continue to stand up for Granite State families and fight against this partisan attempt to undermine healthcare coverage in this country. Republican leadership in Congress should withdraw this disastrous bill and work with Democrats to improve the Affordable Care Act. – J.S.

I voted NO on Seema Verma’s nomination to serve as Administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. I cannot support the confirmation of a CMS Administrator who supports drastic cuts that would threaten healthcare coverage for children, seniors, people with disabilities, and patients receiving treatment for substance use disorders. I also have deep concerns about Ms. Verma’s commitment to protecting women’s health care, as she believes that prenatal care and maternity coverage should be strictly optional. This position harkens back to when being a woman was a pre-existing condition and insurance companies could charge women more for health insurance. – J.S.

I want to thank Phil for sharing the story of his remarkable recovery and the role that Medicaid played in providing substance misuse disorder treatment. Phil is just one of the tens of thousands of Granite Staters who rely on Medicaid for their healthcare needs. Trumpcare’s drastic Medicaid cuts put their health at risk and undermine our efforts to combat the opioid epidemic. Trumpcare also would require older Americans to pay much higher premiums and increase cost for care across the board. I promise to stand with Phil to protect the Medicaid program and work to further improve the Affordable Care Act, rather than supporting Republican leadership's reckless, partisan attempt to repeal the law.

ICYMI: Last night I spoke with Greta Van Susteren about my concerns with the Republican healthcare plan. President Trump promised “insurance for everybody,” but under the Republican plan Americans will pay more and get less. Instead of moving forward on this disastrous bill, we need to come together on a bipartisan basis to improve the Affordable Care Act. - J.S.

Yesterday on the Senate floor, I spoke in favor of the Afghan Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) program, which provides refuge to Afghans who served alongside our troops and diplomats and are under threat from terrorists because of their service. In light of the news that the U.S. embassy in Kabul officially stopped scheduling interviews for the Afghan SIV program, I introduced the “Keeping Our Promise to Our Afghan Allies Act.” This bipartisan legislation will authorize an additional 2,500 SIVs for Afghans, people like Keene resident Patmana Rafiq Kunary. I was fortunate to meet Patmana last month, and she told me about her work with the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) in Kabul. Patmana became vice president for operations at the USAID-sponsored microloan program, but because of her work she became a high-profile target for the Taliban and others. Patmana was able to apply for a SIV and now lives very happily in Keene with her husband and two-year-old daughter. We made a solemn promise to brave Afghans like Patmana, and I am going to do everything I can to ensure that we keep this promise. - J.S.

After reviewing the budget outline released by the Trump administration, I suggest they immediately go back to the drawing board. This budget is a blueprint for undermining the health and well-being of Granite Staters and would be particularly devastating for seniors. It’s needless and cruel to drastically cut programs that so many people in New Hampshire depend on like Meals on Wheels and heating assistance. It also makes no sense to cut clean air and water programs, coastal protection, and economic development to struggling rural communities. This budget outline also makes us less safe by decimating our nation’s diplomatic corps and underfunding airport security. I’ve always sought bipartisan cooperation to find savings across the federal government, but this can done without disproportionately targeting programs that are so important to New Hampshire. Republicans and Democrats agree that there should be continued investments in these programs and President Trump should expect broad bipartisan opposition to this mindless proposal. – J.S.

The Chinese government recently awarded President Trump 38 trademarks for various business dealings which comes after years of unsuccessful filing efforts by Trump’s legal team. These trademarks to market the Trump name for profit in China were announced shortly after President Trump spoke with President Xi Jinping and affirmed the continuation of the United States’ One-China policy. The timing of these trademarks raises serious ethical concerns. The U.S. Constitution forbids the President and other office holders from accepting foreign payments without authorization by Congress. President Trump’s ongoing failure to resolve his conflicts of interest and divest himself from his business entanglements creates serious trust issues. The Office of Government Ethics needs to weigh in on whether the award betrays ethics laws, policies, or established norms. More here:   https://www.shaheen.senate.gov/news/press/shaheen-hassan-ask-ethics-watchdog-if-trump-trademarks-run-afoul-of-constitution-and-anti-bribery-laws

Happy St. Patrick’s Day! The Irish were some of the first immigrants to arrive in New Hampshire. Today we celebrate Ireland’s proud heritage and all that the Irish people have contributed to the Granite State and our country. Sláinte! – J.S.

Yesterday, ahead of St. Patrick’s Day, Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny spoke at the White House. He provided timely words on how Irish immigrants were once discriminated against, yet they persisted and believed in the shelter, the compassion, and the opportunity of America. They became Americans and have contributed so much to our nation. Immigrants make up the fabric of this country, and they continue to enrich our communities and strengthen our economy.

This week I delivered the National Democratic Address in response to President Trump and Republican leadership’s efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act. For millions of everyday Americans, health coverage isn’t about politics, it’s a matter of life and death. In dozens of visits to New Hampshire during the campaign, President Trump promised aggressive action to fight the opioid and heroine epidemic. He promised never to cut Medicare and Medicaid, and that no one would lose health coverage. But with this new Republican plan, millions of Americans will lose their health coverage, and those who keep it will pay much more. It will have especially tragic consequences for New Hampshire and other states fighting the heroin and opioid epidemic. Under Trumpcare, 1.3 million Americans now in treatment for mental health and substance use disorders would lose their health coverage. This new legislation takes us in the wrong direction. Congress should stop, take a deep breath, and work together to find a better way forward. Let’s keep our promises to the American people, so that millions do not lose their health coverage. And let’s come together to strengthen what’s working, and fix what’s not. – J.S.

President Trump’s budget completely eliminates the Northern Border Regional Commission which continues to invest millions towards economic development in the Northern New Hampshire, including in Coos, Grafton, Carroll and Sullivan counties. The NBRC has provided funding for infrastructure developments and treatment and recovery services to help battle the opioid epidemic. These cuts would be a real blow to New Hampshire’s northern rural economy, and I will strongly oppose these shortsighted cuts.

Today the Senate recognizes the first ever National Rosie the Riveter Day, supported by a Senate resolution I sponsored to acknowledge the immeasurable contributions that ‘Rosies’ made to our country during World War II and beyond. When husbands and sons were sent off to war, women in New Hampshire and across the country stepped up to the plate to lead American manufacturing. Their role in the workforce broke barriers, reshaped the economy, and changed the futures of millions of women and girls who followed. It’s fitting that this day falls during Women’s History Month, a time we reflect on the many ways women have helped form our great nation. - J.S.

Billy and I were very saddened to learn of the passing of Scott McGilvray. Scott’s devotion to public service grew out of his passion for students. Whether on the football field, in the classroom or in the New Hampshire Senate, Scott worked tirelessly to help New Hampshire’s children reach their full potential. Scott’s legacy will live on in the many Granite Staters whose lives he changed. I extend my deepest condolences to Scott’s wife Patti, his daughters and his family. My thoughts are with them as we all mourn his passing. - J.S.

In recent years, I’ve gotten to know former Army Captain Michael Breen, a Granite Stater who served with the infantry in Iraq and led paratroopers in Afghanistan. He has spoken with admiration about Wissam, an Iraqi woman who served alongside his unit as an interpreter. Wissam took great risks and gave her life while serving with Captain Breen and the United States. To honor her memory, as well as the brave Afghan interpreters who work serve side by side with our troops, Congress must ensure the Special Immigrant Visas program does not lapse. That’s why I introduced my bipartisan Keep Our Promise to Our Afghan Allies Act, which would authorize additional SIVs. We made a solemn promise to these brave Afghans, I am going to do everything I can to ensure that we keep this promise. - J.S.

Today, I joined with Senator Maggie Hassan to introduce legislation that will overhaul the Department of Veteran Affairs’ appeal process and expedite appeals before the Board of Veterans Appeals and give veterans clear options after receiving an initial decision. The convoluted appeals system that our veterans currently face says to men and women who dutifully served their country to take a number, get in line and wait, often for years. Our veterans deserve an appeals process that makes sense and allows claims to be processed in a timely manner, not a complicated process of red tape. The VA Appeals Modernization Act is a smart bill to help fix this broken system. – J.S.

I joined a bipartisan group of my colleagues to call on Defense Secretary James Mattis to better combat sexual harassment in the military after it was discovered that a Facebook group run by active duty and Reserve Marines posted explicit photos of women service members. These reports are very disturbing and unacceptable, and our letter to Secretary Mattis demands that the Pentagon develop a proactive plan to eliminate intimidation, harassment, and reprisal online and in the barracks. The Department of Defense must take proactive steps to discover and eliminate all forms of service members’ online harassment. The women of the Marine Corps serve with honor and dignity, and the military has a responsibility to all service members to eliminate degrading behavior online long before it affects unit cohesion and readiness. – J.S.

I spent the afternoon touring the Manchester Job Corps Center and addressed the women students as part of Women's History Month. We had a great discussion about women's leadership in the workplace. I also want to thank the Manchester Job Corps Center for the great work that they do, equipping youth with the skills they need to be successful in the workplace. This pays dividends for not only these young people, but for our economy as a whole.

Republican leadership’s decision to pull the Affordable Care Act repeal vote is proof that your voice matters. Thank you to everyone who called, emailed, and made your voices heard. I also want to thank everyone who sent in their personal healthcare stories and shared with me how much this law meant to you and your families. You helped show Congress that healthcare isn’t just about the numbers – it’s about people and families and their health and well-being. It’s time for President Trump and Republican leadership to work across the aisle to improve healthcare to bring down costs and expand coverage. I’ve successfully worked across the aisle to improve the Affordable Care Act, proving that it can be done! There’s more work to do here and I’m eager to make more progress for New Hampshire and the country. – J.S.

This is what Senator Shaheen had to say after President Trump signed an Executive Order to reverse climate change initiatives put in place by President Obama:  President Trump is ignoring the mountain of evidence on climate change and plowing ahead with a dangerous agenda that threatens the health and well-being of New Hampshire. Rolling back carbon emissions rules and clean energy initiatives is a shortsighted political move that prioritizes the interests of big oil and coal companies over every day Americans. In New Hampshire, we see the effects of climate change every day and it is a direct threat to our environment, economy and way of life. We owe it to future generations to build on the Clean Power Plan and the Paris Agreement in order to avoid the worst impacts of climate change. I will fight President Trump’s actions in the Senate and have joined several of my colleagues in introducing legislation to rescind the President’s Executive Order. – J.S.

After meeting with Judge Gorsuch and reviewing his record and testimony, I cannot support his nomination to serve on the Supreme Court. His record on women’s reproductive rights is very troubling and, despite the many questions raised to him during his nomination hearing, he did not provide any assurances that he would defend the important precedent of Roe v. Wade. I cannot support a Supreme Court justice who would turn back the clock on women’s reproductive rights. In addition, he has a very alarming record of putting the interests of large corporations over those of their employees. I was also disheartened by his evasive answers to questions regarding the Citizens United decision, which has dramatically increased the amount of secret money in politics. When President Obama nominated Judge Garland, Republican leadership immediately blocked his nomination, preventing a hearing and a vote. Despite this unprecedented obstruction by the Republican majority, I remain committed to upholding the constitution’s instruction to advise and consent on Supreme Court nominations. As Judge Gorsuch’s nomination comes to the floor, I will support a 60-vote threshold for approval, an appropriate high bar that has been met by seven of the eight current Supreme Court justices. – J.S.

Diabetes is personal for many of us. Today’s Diabetes Alert Day is an important reminder to learn about the risk factors for type 2 diabetes and take the test. Take control of your health and join the fight to prevent type 2 diabetes . – J.S.

This is what Senator Shaheen had to say regarding President Trump’s announcement of a new commission to address the opioid epidemic:   I welcome the establishment of this commission and am committed to working with the administration to battle the opioid epidemic. But this administration’s policies in regards to the opioid crisis are in desperate need of a course correction and I hope this commission will help facilitate a turnaround before New Hampshire’s efforts are severely undermined. There is a massive gulf between President Trump’s promises to tackle this crisis and the policies this administration has proposed during his first two months in office.   The President just tried to repeal the Affordable Care Act, ending Medicaid expansion, which would have taken away substance misuse and mental health treatment from thousands of Granite Staters. His administration has also proposed drastic budget cuts to many programs that New Hampshire depends on to fight this epidemic every day. This commission should immediately reevaluate these funding cuts and identify additional resources to help people on the frontlines in New Hampshire and other states who are doing heroic work to save lives. I also strongly encourage President Trump and Governor Christie to seek their counsel. President Trump made a promise to the Granite State to provide more treatment and end the opioid crisis, and he must keep that promise. - J.S.

President Trump’s budget proposal drastically cuts programs that many Granite State families depend on. His budget eliminates the 21st Century Community Learning Centers program which helps fund 32 New Hampshire after-school programs that support 6,000 students. We know that engaging children in high-quality after-school programs helps students’ performance in grades, test scores, attendance, participation rates, and graduation. I will continue to fight for New Hampshire’s after-school programs and will work across the aisle to oppose these cuts.—J.S.

I’m very disappointed that the Senate passed Republican leadership’s legislation today allowing discrimination against family planning providers. Make no mistake about it, the primary target of this legislation is Planned Parenthood. Earlier today, I went to the Senate floor to speak out against this misguided resolution. For years now, Republican leaders in Congress have attempted to defund this essential healthcare provider, which serves millions of women nationwide, including nearly 12,000 Granite Staters. Why weren’t the Republican senators who supported the resolution willing to come to the Senate floor to defend their action, which jeopardizes essential care for millions of women? I’ll continue to fight in the Senate on behalf of Granite Staters who depend on Planned Parenthood for their healthcare and urge my colleagues to do the same. – J.S.

ICYMI: Yesterday I introduced legislation to help schools, communities and youth athletic associations provide prevention programs to reduce substance misuse among students and student athletes. Student athletes are particularly at risk for substance misuse due to prescription opioids used to treat sports injuries. A study at the University of Michigan found that youth athletes in high-injury sports have a 50 percent higher odds of non-medical use of prescription opioids. To stem the tide of the opioid crisis, we must combat it from all angles and my legislation would help protect students and their athletic communities. – J.S.

Access to a fair day in court shouldn’t be a luxury. However, President Trump’s budget proposal eliminates funding for legal assistance programs for those Granite Staters who can’t afford it. Low-income families and individuals face so many obstacles – access to legal protection and representation shouldn’t be one of them. Instead of eliminating this critical service, we should be working to expand access to legal services for our communities. I’m fighting these wrongheaded cuts in the Senate because everyone deserves justice in our legal system – not just those who can afford it. - J.S.

Today marks Equal Pay Day, a call to action to fight the pay discrimination that undermines our country’s fundamental principles of equality. As long as millions of American women continue to only earn 79 cents for every dollar earned by men, we have to keep fighting. Equal Pay Day is an important reminder that, despite recent progress, we still have a long way to go to end pay discrimination. A recent study projected that the wage gap in New Hampshire will close in 2079. Waiting 62 years to close the wage gap is just unacceptable, hurting Granite State women, their families and our economy. It’s time to make equal pay for equal work a reality. – J.S.
Big congrats to Puritan Backroom on your 100th birthday! Here’s to 100 more years of delicious chicken tenders & ice cream. - J.S.

Behind closed doors with no fanfare, President Trump signed legislation that allows your internet service provider to sell your private information without your knowledge or consent. It’s understandable why he didn’t want cameras in the room. This is very personal information that includes private citizens’ browser history, Social Security Numbers, email contents, precise location and more. I’m dismayed that Republican leadership jammed this legislation through Congress in just a couple of days -- this policy undermines the privacy of millions of Americans! I voted against this legislation and strongly urged President Trump to veto it. Considering all of the many issues this Congress should be addressing, the President and Republican leadership should explain why exposing Granite Stater’s private information was such a high priority. The public deserves answers. – J.S.

With Secretary of State Rex Tillerson set to travel to Russia later this month, Senator Marco Rubio and I formally requested that Secretary Tillerson meet with Russian civil society groups. Just this past weekend, the world watched as more than 1,500 anti-corruption protesters were arrested by Russian state security forces across the country, while many more protesters were violently dispersed. Democratically-minded Russians should know that the U.S. supports their aspirations, and as our nation’s top diplomat, Secretary Tillerson is in a unique position to communicate this message.– J.S.

This is what Senator Shaheen had to say after Republican leadership's decision to change long-standing rules in order to confirm Supreme Court nominee Judge Neil Gorsuch:  Judge Gorsuch has an alarming record of putting the interests of large corporations over those of their employees. He also has frequently ruled against women’s reproductive rights and has been extremely evasive on his position on Citizens United, a decision that has dramatically increased the amount of secret money in politics. It’s very disappointing that Republican leadership is changing the rules to approve his nomination and again, resorting to unprecedented tactics to shape the Supreme Court. I’m committed to upholding the Constitution’s instruction to advise and consent on Supreme Court nominations. Rather than changing this long-standing Senate rule, Republican leadership should urge President Trump to put forward a nominee who has a track record of treating women and workers even handedly in our legal system, and who would be approved with a strong bipartisan vote. - J.S.

In 2013 when Bashar al-Assad used chemical weapons on his own people, I voted to support military action. Since then, Assad’s brutality has continued unabated. His use of chemical weapons on innocent civilians has struck the moral conscience of the United States and the world.  I’m supportive of the Trump administration’s decision to launch air strikes in response to Assad’s assault on his own people. Going forward, President Trump must explain to the American people what his strategy is to bring the broader Syrian conflict to a close and end the threat of terrorism that this conflict has fueled. Congress must also provide constructive oversight. Furthermore, this administration must be fully transparent with Congress and the American people regarding troop deployments to the battlefield. - J.S.

The United States needs a bold, aggressive strategy to respond to Russia’s efforts to undermine our democratic institutions and our European alliance. I will continue to call for an independent, non-partisan investigation on Russia’s attack on our democracy. We need to acknowledge that our country has been attacked by a hostile foreign power and this calls for tough measures to punish and deter Russia. -- J.S.  More in my op-ed published in the Portsmouth Herald: http://www.seacoastonline.com/news/20170407/what-granite-staters-need-to-know-about-russia

I’m introducing bipartisan legislation that will help local communities identify emerging contaminants in drinking water. Granite State families who are worried about their children getting sick from drinking contaminated water deserve peace of mind, and my legislation addresses barriers that limit the Environmental Protection Agency response to emerging contaminants. This bill bolsters cooperation between the EPA and local communities and also makes agency resources more easily accessible. It gives our communities the tools they need to research, identify and treat emerging contaminants. -- J.S.  More here: http://www.seacoastonline.com/news/20170410/shaheen-bill-takes-aim-at-water-contamination

I want to thank all the first responders for their bravery and service. While I'm thankful that no one was hurt, my thoughts are with the owners and staff of State Street Saloon and the residents displaced by the fire. It's heartening to see the community come together to offer assistance and help these people get back on their feet. - J.S.

Congratulations to Matthew Desmond on his Pulitzer Prize for “Evicted,” a deep look at the link between poverty and housing in our country. In his book, Desmond looked at the impact of domestic violence and sexual assault, compounded by nuisance ordinances, that cause women to get evicted for violence committed against them. Desmond has helped bring attention to this important issue, and his research helped inform my legislation that tackles this head on. My bill, which I reintroduced last week, would establish a nationwide standard that survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault cannot be evicted or denied access to housing solely for being victims of those crimes. Domestic violence and sexual assault survivors have so many obstacles to overcome, and safe, reliable housing should not be one of them. -- J.S.  Read coverage by Mic to learn more about the issue: https://mic.com/articles/148484/domestic-violence-victims-can-be-evicted-for-calling-police-here-s-why#.DKySMCwnW

I had a wonderful time with Shaker Road’s 3rd Graders this morning, who featured me in their Women’s History Month Project. I’m honored that they chose me for their project and I want to thank them for all their hard work. They did such a great job! - J.S.

I had a busy day in Laconia and Concord today. After stopping by to visit 3rd graders at Shaker Road School to see their project, I visited BittWare, one of the top-ranked small businesses in New Hampshire. I had an opportunity to tour their impressive facility and discuss workforce development. BittWare has been successful at recruiting and retaining a skilled workforce. Following that visit, I joined Senator Maggie Hassan at a press conference calling out President Trump’s budget proposal, which would eliminate the Community Development Block Grant program which supports housing, economic development, substance misuse treatment centers in New Hampshire, and many other vital projects here in New Hampshire. Then I visited Genesis Behavioral Health, which is one of 10 New Hampshire community mental health centers pioneering the Military Liaison Initiative. This first in the nation program is helping veterans, service members and families connect with vital mental health services. I ended my day by visiting the Portsmouth Fire Department. I was able to thank them for their service and for their response to the fire at the State Street Saloon.

I spent today in Claremont and the Upper Valley, starting with a visit to Costa Precision Manufacturing, a small business that specializes in high-end metal manufacturing. Costa Precision recently became certified under the Historically Underutilized Business Zone Program (HUBZone) program, which gives small businesses who locate in economically challenged communities a better shot at competing for federal contracts. Next, during a quick stop at The Lebanon Diner, I ran into Lebanon Fire Chief Chris Christopoulos and Police Chief Richard Miello and I was able to thank them for their service. Afterwards I headed to River Valley Community College’s Lebanon campus, which provides workforce and job training programs for the Upper Valley. An investment by the Northern Border Regional Commission (NBRC) helped make it all possible. President Trump’s budget proposal would eliminate the NBRC and at River Valley Community College, I talked about the importance of this program and my strong opposition to eliminating it. I was able to end my day speaking at the New Hampshire Association of Fire Chief’s annual meeting. - J.S.

Today behind closed doors, President Trump signed legislation to block funding to Planned Parenthood that will leave women and their families with fewer healthcare options. Women’s healthcare, including family planning services, are essential to our wellbeing, and this legislation will put that essential care out of reach for far too many women. I’ll continue to fight in the Senate on behalf of the 12,000 Granite State women who depend on Planned Parenthood for their healthcare. -- J.S.
I’ll be hosting a town hall this Thursday in Nashua. I hope you can attend! -- J.S.
I'm looking forward to tomorrow's town hall. I hope you can attend! -- J.S.

This morning, I spoke with University of New Hampshire faculty about my opposition to the President's budget proposal, which would cut research funding for UNH grants and impact the local economy. -- J.S.

I spent the day on the seacoast in Durham and Londonderry. I started at the University of New Hampshire, where I spoke with faculty about my opposition to the President’s budget proposal, which threatens UNH research funding. UNH received approximately $80 million in federal funding last year for research which helps support local breakthroughs across a wide range of industries and boosts the regional economy. Afterwards I was able to stop by and speak with UNH’s Fight4HER group, Planned Parenthood of New Hampshire, and Population Connection Action Fund about protecting women’s healthcare. We also discussed my efforts to repeal the Global Gag Rule, which withholds foreign aid to non-governmental organizations that provide services or information relating to abortion as a part of comprehensive family planning services. After UNH, I visited Admix, a small business that specializes in creating commercial mixing equipment. I was able to learn about their program that gives employees a stake in the company and builds their workforce. - J.S.
It was great to see so many people attend this evening's town hall. Thank you all for taking time out of your day to attend and for all your questions. -- J.S.

My staff in Manchester and I are wearing purple today for the 7th annual #PurpleUp For Military Kids. In New Hampshire, there are 5,200 military children who join their family in serving our country. We support you and thank you!

Happy Earth Day! Today, let’s recommit to fighting climate change so that we leave a better world for our children and their children. Preserving our environment is an area where every Granite Stater can make a difference.
Today, ahead of Earth Day, I joined a volunteer beach cleanup in Hampton. We must commit to preserving our world for future generations!

Sexual assault remains one of the most underreported crimes in our justice system and we must do all we can to improve the way our justice system treats survivors. Those who have been sexually assaulted have a basic right to privacy, including their past sexual history, and SB9 as written will ensure Granite State survivors are given basic privacy protections. I support the Marriot family in their path to justice for Lizzi, and the New Hampshire legislature should pass SB9, which will strengthen our Rape Shield Law and will help encourage survivors to report their assault and cooperate with prosecution. -- J.S.

Today I met with Governor Chris Christie who is Chairman of the President’s recently-established commission tasked with recommending policies to address the opioid crisis. During our meeting, I strongly urged Chairman Christie to follow through on President Trump’s promise to New Hampshire to provide urgently needed resources to our communities. I was very clear that the Affordable Care Act’s Medicaid expansion has been critical to treatment gains for Granite Staters, and that New Hampshire and other states cannot afford repeal of the Medicaid expansion as part of any new healthcare deal. I also urged him to revise the funding formula so that New Hampshire gets a more appropriate share of federal funding through the 21st Century Cures Act. This is a life or death situation for many Granite Staters and this administration has many tools at its disposal to help New Hampshire turn the corner on this crisis. That’s why I remain committed to working with the Trump Administration to finally treat this epidemic like the public health emergency that it is. – J.S.

My thoughts after my meeting at the White House with Governor Chris Christie who is the Chairman of the president’s recently-established commission tasked with recommending policies to address the opioid crisis:

My bipartisan legislation to establish a national commission of health care experts to advance diabetes care and prevention is headed to the Senate floor after being unanimously passed by the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (HELP) Committee this morning. Millions of Americans and their families are affected by diabetes and experts predict that number will continue to grow. My legislation will ensure that the federal government is equipped to streamline and leverage investments in diabetes research, prevention, and treatment. Establishing a National Clinical Care Commission will set us on the right track to reverse the human and economic toll of this disease. Together we can find a cure. – J.S.

I strongly encourage every household in New Hampshire to check their cabinets for highly addictive prescriptions. New Hampshire has been devastated by the opioid epidemic, and we all need to be vigilant about removing excess painkillers from our homes not only on Drug Take-Back Day, but every day. Drug take-back programs are an effective way to help safeguard your family and community and I hope we can break a participation record this Saturday. -- J.S. Great to join the People’s Climate March in Concord today. We must take action, stop climate change & preserve our planet for future generations.

Good news! One of my top priorities in the Senate has been to secure more resources for those in New Hampshire who are on the frontlines of the opioid epidemic. As a member of the committee that funds the government from year-to-year, at every opportunity I’ve been advocating for resources to battle this crisis. Today, I’m happy to say some more help is on the way. A bipartisan agreement was reached last night to fund the government that provides a significant increase in funding for treatment and law enforcement. Law enforcement and treatment providers are in desperate need of this help. Until we get control of this crisis, I'll continue to fight for funding to support life-saving efforts. – J.S.

The Trump administration just announced that it is discontinuing Michelle Obama’s landmark Let Girls Learn initiative, which brought much-needed attention to the unique obstacles that young girls face in getting an education around the world. Far too often, young girls are kept from school because of societal norms and family obligations. I will soon introduce legislation, the Keeping Girls in School Act, to ensure that the United States remains committed to addressing the unique barriers that adolescent girls around the world face in accessing a quality, equitable education. We must stand with adolescent girls everywhere who are deprived of an education and denied the opportunity to reach their full potential. - J.S.
Senator Hassan and I got to meet Rumor, the 2017 Westminster Best in Show winner! Definitely the highlight of the evening. - J.S.

Teresa Manning has spent her career denying science and peddling fiction about family planning and abortion. Her appointment to oversee our nation’s family planning program is yet another step in the Trump Administration’s dangerous campaign to roll back women’s reproductive rights and undermine the immense progress we have made to reduce teen pregnancy and abortions, both at an all-time low, in part because of funding through the Title X family planning program. We need someone in this key position who understands how to reduce teen pregnancies, the importance of empowering women through access to family planning services, and who is committed to reducing the number of unplanned pregnancies in our country. Make no mistake, family planning is not simply a health issue – this is an economic issue for all women and their families. -- J.S.    http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2017/05/02/trump_will_tap_teresa_manning_a_woman_who_thinks_birth_control_doesn_t_work.html

As a part of Small Business Week, I’m about to speak at the Hill’s Main Street Matters event and discuss how we can support our small businesses. You can watch it here:  http://thehill.com/event/323662-main-street-matter-jobs-wages-the-small-business-economy

Today I spoke on the Senate floor about the important role small businesses play in creating jobs and growing the American economy.  Outstanding New Hampshire entrepreneurs, like the owners of Popzup and Celdara Medical, have created thriving businesses with assistance from the U.S. Small Business Administration. -- J.S.

President Trump and Republican leadership have recklessly rushed legislation through the House that would be devastating to the health and wellbeing of New Hampshire. This bill dramatically reduces healthcare coverage across the country, increases costs for patients, and eliminates protections that prevent insurance companies from discriminating against patients with pre-existing conditions. Under this bill, insurance companies could discriminate on a wide-range of conditions and circumstances, including history of cancer, heart disease, C-sections, postpartum depression and even being the victim of sexual assault or domestic violence. It also eliminates funding for Planned Parenthood, jeopardizing access to vital preventative care services that more than 12,000 Granite State women rely on to live healthy lives, care for their families, and lead in the workforce.   It’s also unconscionable that, as New Hampshire battles one of the worst public health crises in our state’s history, this legislation eliminates coverage for mental health and substance misuse treatment that is critical to our response to the opioid epidemic.   This bill profoundly demonstrates why Congress needs to work together to improve the Affordable Care Act, rather than repeal it. There’s bipartisan opposition to this disastrous repeal legislation in the Senate and I intend to work across the aisle to stop this plan in its tracks. Too many lives in New Hampshire depend on the coverage and protections that this bill eliminates. - J.S.

I want to hear from you! If you have a question you’d like to ask me, leave it in the comments section of this post. Next week, I’ll choose a few questions to respond to in a video message from my office. I may not be able to get to all of your questions, but I’ll try to get to as many of them as I can. – J.S.

Editorial boards are calling out House Republican’s healthcare repeal bill and the disastrous impact it would have on the health and well-being of Americans across the country. The Concord Monitor wrote, “The act, passed in a rush with no analysis of its fiscal impact, would cut $880 billion from Medicaid, the health care program for people with low or no income. It allows insurers to charge older people five times the rates charged younger people, up from three times under Obamacare. It lets states apply for waivers that would permit them to drop the existing requirement that they insure people with pre-existing conditions.” I intend to work across the aisle to stop this plan in its tracks. – J.S.  Read the Monitor’s article here: http://www.concordmonitor.com/A-cruel-health-care-bill-9699002
