President Trump’s firing of FBI Director Comey is very disturbing and opens a Pandora’s box of additional questions regarding the ongoing investigation into Russia’s interference in the 2016 election. This unprecedented interference by the President of the United States in an ongoing criminal investigation leaves no doubt that the only way to uncover the truth about Russian interference in our election is with an independent investigation. It’s well past time for Republicans in Congress to put country above party and support the appointment of an independent counsel. The American public has a right to know to what end Russia interfered in our election. Now more than ever, there should be a bipartisan agreement to get to the bottom of this.--J.S.

This is what Senator Shaheen had to say after President Trump's Secretary for Health and Human Services visited New Hampshire today on a "listening tour" on the opioid crisis:   Considering Secretary Price played a lead role in crafting the Republican leadership’s healthcare repeal bill, I hope that he will take to heart the significant concerns of Granite Staters who are extremely alarmed about the impact that this legislation would have on their lives. Today, Secretary Price said the Trump administration’s focus is to provide coverage and care to every American, but his words don’t match the administration’s actions. The Republican leadership’s healthcare repeal bill decimates Medicaid, and eliminates the program’s expansion and the federal requirement that insurance plans cover substance misuse treatment.  Taken together, these policies would not only take a wrecking ball to our state’s progress to address the opioid epidemic, but put us in a far worse position than ever before. These tools are fundamental to New Hampshire’s efforts to provide treatment to Granite Staters who desperately need it. Needless to say, a listening tour would have been much more appropriate prior to pushing this healthcare repeal legislation through the House of Representatives without any hearings. --JS

Thank you to everyone who submitted a question for our first Facebook Q&A. The majority of the questions we received were focused on Russia's intervention in our election and the effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act, so those are the topics I'm addressing today. Keep submitting questions and I'll get to them soon. -- J.S.

Busy day in Salem, Derry and Manchester talking about issues facing Granite Staters. I started the morning with Senator Hassan at an event hosted by the Greater Salem and Greater Derry Londonderry Chambers of Commerce, where we discussed what’s happening in Washington and took questions. While there, I got to meet Air Force academy nominee Adam Morris and several Salem High Seniors. Next, I stopped by Rockingham Brewing Company, a small business that will be participating in the 8th Annual Experience New Hampshire event I will be hosting in Washington in June. I ended the day with a visit to the Mental Health Center of Greater Manchester. I met with mental health professionals for a roundtable discussion about veteran healthcare and the impact the Republican leadership’s healthcare repeal bill would have on veteran’s access to care. -- J.S.
Happy Mother's Day! I wish everyone the best as they celebrate the mothers, grandmothers, and influential women in their lives. -- J.S.

This is what Senator Shaheen had to say after learning that the Trump Administration’s expanded Mexico City Policy, also known as the Global Gag Rule, will apply to $8.8 billion in U.S. foreign aid. The Mexico City Policy bans federal funds for international non-governmental organizations that provide provide information about abortion or provide abortion services as part of family planning services:   Today, the Trump administration confirmed our worst fears regarding this new, drastically expanded global gag executive order. This administration's pathetic rebranding of this policy ‎is a thinly-veiled attempt to hide the tremendous harm it has around the world. President Trump's dangerous obsession with rolling back reproductive rights has severe consequences for millions of vulnerable women and children, and grossly undermines our nation's humanitarian leadership around the globe. We know that when family planning services and contraceptives are easily accessible, there are fewer unplanned pregnancies, maternal deaths, and abortions. Yet the Trump administration has chosen to ignore decades of research in favor of an ideological crusade that cuts off vital family planning services. President Trump’s actions have already had a chilling effect on international humanitarian efforts, preventing cooperation on a wide range of life-saving work to prevent the spread of HIV/AIDS, Zika and other preventable diseases. Today's announcement underscores the need for Congress to pass my bipartisan Global HER Act to repeal this global gag policy once and for all. – J.S.

This morning, former NFL player Jeff Hatch and I spoke to Portsmouth High School students about preventing substance misuse among students and student athletes. Student athletes are particularly at risk for substance misuse due to prescription opioids used to treat sports injuries. It's critical that we engage the school and athletic communities in the fight to prevent substance misuse and end the opioid epidemic, which is why I introduced the Student and Student Athlete Opioid Misuse Prevention Act earlier this year. To end this crisis, we must combat this epidemic from all angles and bolstering prevention programs among our students and student athletes is one important piece of this puzzle. – J.S.
Here’s my reaction to reports that President Trump disclosed classified information to Russian officials. -- J.S.

Earlier today, I hosted a meeting with former Senator Scott Brown in my office. This was an opportunity to congratulate him in-person on his nomination to be Ambassador to New Zealand and Samoa, and discuss the job. I wished him the best of luck in his hearing this week and in this new position, and reiterated my support for his nomination. -- J.S.

President Trump promised to provide more treatment resources to New Hampshire to help end the opioid epidemic, but so far his administration has only put forward policies that would be a massive setback. Yesterday, I led a group of senators from states hardest hit by the opioid epidemic to call on President Trump to stick to his word. – J.S

Throughout New Hampshire, Granite Staters are struggling with the increasing costs of higher education and it’s hurting students, their families and our economy. Students should be able to refinance their loans just like homeowners can refinance their mortgages. Along with my Democratic colleagues, I’m introducing the Bank on Students Emergency Loan Refinancing Act, which would allow those with outstanding student loan debt to refinance at lower interest rates. This legislation will help borrowers save thousands on their loans, continuing our effort to make college more affordable and help save students from a mountain of debt. – J.S.

This is a very trying time for our country. Like many of you, I’ve been very disturbed by news of President Trump’s actions and behavior, particularly reports that he may have tried to undermine investigations into Russia’s interference in the 2016 election and potentially turned over highly classified information to Russian officials in a private meeting. There should be a bipartisan agreement to get to the bottom of this. I’m encouraged that, finally, these latest revelations have spurred a few Republicans to join Democrats in calling for an independent investigation. But frankly, we need many more Republicans in Congress to put country above party and support the appointment of an independent counsel. Americans have a right to know the full story about Russia’s interference in the 2016 election, and they need assurance that our government is taking steps to prevent it from happening again.   In addition to an independent investigation, we need former FBI Director James Comey to testify again before Congress in a public hearing and I strongly support efforts to subpoena documents that detail his communications with President Trump. These documents could go a long ways towards determining the nature of President Trump’s discussions with Director Comey. Last week, after it was revealed that Director Comey was fired soon after requesting additional funding for the FBI’s Russia investigation, I sent a letter with Senator Patrick Leahy (D-VT) to the Department of Justice requesting the specifics of this request and how it was processed. It’s critical that the FBI receives the needed personnel and resources to conduct this investigation thoroughly.    Finally, I’ve been calling on the administration to conduct a classified briefing so that Congress understands specifically what classified information was disclosed to Russian officials. The United States has many important relationships with allies who contribute to our national security by sharing intelligence about terrorists and other threats to our country. It’s been reported that the information the President provided to the Russians was shared by Israel, a key ally. It’s important to note that Russia is allied with Iran and Syria, both countries that call for the destruction of Israel. Sharing intelligence with adversaries undermines our critical relationships, compromises sources of intelligence in the field, and, ultimately, threatens our national security.   As a member of both the Senate Armed Services and Foreign Relations Committees, I will continue to call for accountability and oversight of the Trump administration on these critical matters of national security. We cannot allow partisanship to prevent us from getting the facts and taking action to protect our national security and our democracy! -- J.S.

This morning, I visited Fairview Healthcare in Hudson to meet with nursing home staff and discuss the devastating impact that the Senate Republican healthcare repeal bill's proposed Medicaid cuts would have on seniors and people with disabilities in nursing homes across our state. 63% of nursing home residents in New Hampshire use Medicaid to pay for their care. In addition, nursing homes account for 42% of all Medicaid expenditures, so they would bear a disproportionate share of any Medicaid cuts. Our seniors deserve better and it's why I'm fighting this bill in the Senate. I'm urging my colleagues to come together on a bipartisan basis to make needed fixes to the Affordable Care Act, not repeal it. -- J.S.

Today is the #NetNeutrality Day of Action. A free and open internet is critical for our economy – it benefits consumers, encourages innovation, protects small businesses, and supports job growth. It is critical that we continue to ensure Americans have equal access to the internet and stand up for strong Net Neutrality rules. -- J.S.

Entrusting others to look after loved ones can be one of the hardest decisions families make. New Hampshire’s nursing homes provide much-needed professional care and attention to Granite State seniors around-the-clock. Over the last two weeks, I’ve met with nursing home administrators from across the state to get their take on the Senate Republican healthcare repeal legislation and they’re not mincing words. Brendan Williams, president and CEO of the New Hampshire Health Care Association, told me that the bill would take a “wrecking ball” to New Hampshire’s long-term care system and result in nursing home closures. That’s because this legislation drastically cuts Medicaid. Sixty-three percent of nursing home residents in New Hampshire rely on Medicaid to pay for their care, and nursing homes account for forty-two percent of all Medicaid expenditures. Ultimately, the Senate Republican healthcare repeal would reduce the quality of care for all nursing home residents and put nursing home care out of reach for many New Hampshire seniors.   It’s hard to overstate how much stress this would put on New Hampshire families. Our seniors deserve to live their lives in comfort and with dignity. That’s why I’m fighting this legislation in the Senate and urging Republicans to work across the aisle to improve the Affordable Care Act, not repeal it. This is what Granite Staters overwhelmingly tell me they want to see in Congress. I know making bipartisan improvements to our health care system is possible because I’ve made them. Senator Tim Scott, a Republican from South Carolina, and I worked together on a bill that improved Obamacare for small and mid-sized businesses that passed the Senate and the House unanimously and was signed into law. The country needs Democrats and Republicans to work together to expand coverage and lower costs. The health and well-being of the American people is at stake. -- J.S.

Thank you to Eric Adams for all his hard work and compassion to help those with substance use disorders in Laconia. Dedicated public servants like Eric are true heroes to their communities. His efforts are saving lives and giving hope to those who desperately need it. – J.S.

I'm very glad that the Trump administration reversed its decision and will allow the Afghan girls robotics team to travel and compete in the FIRST Global Challenge. --J.S.   http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/12/trump-afghan-girls-robots-240474

In my recent op-ed, I commend the advocacy of all the Pease moms who have campaigned for safe drinking water for their community. In large part thanks to their efforts, my amendment to fund a national perfluorinated chemicals (PFCs) health study for drinking water systems was included in the annual defense bill. Seacoast families deserve peace of mind, and I’ll continue to stand alongside these Pease moms to address this critical health issue. -- J.S.

This is what Senator Shaheen had to say after Senate Republican leadership announced further changes to their legislation to repeal health care:   Senate Republican leaders are not listening to the American people. The fundamentals of this repeal bill have not changed: it would drive up premium costs, eliminate protections for pre-existing conditions, leave millions of working families without coverage, and would undermine our efforts in New Hampshire to combat the opioid epidemic. This legislation still decimates Medicaid and the program’s expansion, which has been a critical tool to providing more substance misuse treatment in New Hampshire, and supports thousands of Granite State children and seniors in nursing homes. The additional funding in this bill for the opioid epidemic doesn’t come close to compensating for the treatment resources that this same bill eliminates.   This bill still eliminates funding for Planned Parenthood, jeopardizing access to vital primary and preventative care services that more than 12,000 Granite State women rely on to live healthy lives, care for their families, and lead in the workforce. Once again, this legislation was an entirely partisan exercise, negotiated behind closed doors with no effort to include input from the other side of the aisle. I will continue to fight this reckless repeal effort and urge my Republican colleagues to work across the aisle to make needed fixes to the Affordable Care Act, not repeal it, so that more Americans have affordable, accessible healthcare. -- J.S.

This morning I was able to meet the Bolton and the McCallum families. Parker Bolton and Sadie McCallum have been able to receive the care they need through the Affordable Care Act and expanded Medicaid. They are two smart young kids and I greatly admire their bravery. -- J.S.

This morning I visited Memorial Hospital in North Conway, whose New Life Programs provides important care and support for prenatal women with substance use disorders. The Senate Republican’s healthcare repeal bill would have a disproportionate impact on rural hospitals like Memorial Hospital and cut off thousands of rural Granite Staters from lifesaving care. Instead of pushing forward with a repeal of the Affordable Care Act, Congress should work across the aisle to fix and strengthen the ACA and ensure rural communities continue to have access to vital healthcare services. – J.S.

This afternoon I was able to speak with nursing home administrators at the St. Vincent de Paul Rehabilitation and Nursing Center in Berlin. We discussed how the proposed Medicaid cuts in Senate Republican’s healthcare repeal bill would have a devastating impact on the care of seniors and people with disabilities. These cuts would not only force seniors out of nursing homes, but also degrade the quality of care for all nursing home residents. It’s time for Senate Republican leadership to listen to the American people and work across the aisle to make improvements to the Affordable Care Act, not repeal it. – J.S.

ICYMI: The New Hampshire Hospital Association, New Hampshire Medical Society and AARP New Hampshire have all come out in opposition to the Senate Republican healthcare repeal bill. They cite how the bill would make drastic cuts to Medicare and Medicaid and remove protections against lifetime limits. I’ll continue to push for bipartisan improvements to the Affordable Care Act, rather than repeal, so that more Americans have affordable, accessible healthcare. -- J.S.

My statement after the latest Senate Republican healthcare repeal bill failed to receive enough support to move forward in the Senate:   The American people have made their voices heard loud and clear: they want more affordable care and better coverage, not legislation that would be disastrous to their health and well-being. In the aftermath of the failure of this latest legislation, I’m encouraged to hear more Republican Senators call for an open and bipartisan process to improve our health care system. President Trump’s plan to move forward with a straight repeal of the Affordable Care Act without a replacement would be even more devastating than the legislation Republican leadership were initially proposing and is a dead-end strategy. This is akin to throwing the American public off a cliff and promising a parachute later. They should instead, seize this moment to work across the aisle and finally do the will of the American people. – J.S.

Fraidoon Akhtari, a former translator who served alongside our troops in Afghanistan, recently came to the U.S. with his family after waiting for nearly five years for a Special Immigrant Visa (SIV). We made a solemn promise to brave Afghans like Fraidoon, who are under threat from terrorists because of their service. I was pleased that my request for 4,000 visas for the SIV program was included in this year’s defense bill. Congress must continue to authorize additional visas and maintain our promise to these Afghan translators and support staff. These brave Afghan men and women, like Fraidoon, risked their lives to fight alongside American armed forces and we must not abandon them. – J.S.

It was such an inspiration to meet the Afghan all-girl robotics team today. They are such bright and courageous young women! It was an honor to give them a Congressional Record statement, in both English and Dari, that memorializes their visit to the United States and applauds them for their courage, creativity, and perseverance. They’ve become an inspiration for young women across the globe, especially for those in developing regions who face barriers to education and opportunity. They told me that they've enjoyed their time in the U.S. (especially the pizza!) and are looking forward to going to a theme park before they return to Afghanistan.    – J.S.
It was great to chat with Refinery29 today after meeting the Afghan all-girls robotics team this morning. -- J.S.

President Trump’s plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act and punt on a replacement, is akin to throwing the American public off a cliff and promising a parachute later. By adopting this strategy, Republican leadership are turning a deaf ear to the American people who do not want to see Congress pass legislation that would be disastrous to their health and well-being. This legislation still decimates Medicaid and the program’s expansion, which has been a critical tool to providing more substance misuse treatment in New Hampshire, and supports thousands of Granite State children and seniors in nursing homes.  There is a growing bipartisan list of lawmakers, myself included, who want to work across the aisle to stabilize the healthcare marketplace and improve coverage. Republican leadership should embrace these efforts and finally do the will of the American people. I’ve introduced legislation that would make good on our commitment to help working families with their deductibles and end the manufactured crisis caused by the Trump administration threatening to withhold this support. The American people want Congress to work across the aisle to fix the problems in our healthcare system and improve coverage for Americans. -- J.S.

The allegations in the Boston Globe report on the Manchester VA are alarming and deeply troubling. No veteran should experience the substandard care described in this report. After being informed of these allegations in a meeting with doctors from the Manchester VA, I raised their concerns with the Office of Special Counsel and the Office of the Inspector General for further investigation. I was encouraged that, following my letter, the Office of Special Counsel followed up on these claims, reached a preliminary assessment, and helped spur an investigation by the VA. It is disappointing that my letter to the Manchester VA, in which VA Secretary Shulkin was copied, was not met with the same urgency. I will continue to work with officials at the VA to investigate these claims and urge that the agency immediately address any shortfalls.  The water damage that occurred at the Manchester VA this morning is also very concerning. My foremost priority is that veterans scheduled for treatment be served at other facilities until the Manchester VA is again fully operational. I’ve been in contact with Acting Director Montoya for an assessment of the damage and was encouraged by the efforts underway to maintain care for veterans that are impacted. Our veterans deserve nothing less than high quality, convenient, accessible health care, and I will not accept anything less.-- J.S.

I was saddened to learn of Senator McCain's brain cancer diagnosis this evening. There are few who have faced tougher battles than cancer in their lives, but John McCain has always demonstrated profound strength in overcoming unimaginable challenges. I know that he will take on this diagnosis with the same mettle and determination we know so well. He is truly one of our nation's greatest living heroes. In New Hampshire, we consider John McCain an honorary Granite Stater and I know the entire state joins with me in wishing him a full recovery. Our thoughts and prayers are with Senator McCain and his family during this difficult time. --J.S.

The Afghan robotics team has become an inspiration for young women across the globe, especially for those in developing regions who face barriers to education and opportunity. It was an honor to meet and thank these brave young women in-person for their perseverance in overcoming the many hurdles they faced in coming to the United States. They have shown what hard work, creativity, and resolve can achieve. -- J.S.

During yesterday’s Appropriations Committee hearing on agriculture, energy and water funding, I co-sponsored an amendment to prevent commercial horse slaughter in the United States. Thank you to everyone who made your voices heard on this issue. – J.S.

Sexual harassment is a direct means of intimidation, and it is extremely dangerous when it occurs in rental housing and impacts women who may not have the financial means to relocate. It’s unacceptable when women are forced to decide between giving in to unwanted sexual advances or becoming homeless. I’ve introduced legislation that will empower survivors and make it easier for women to report these offenses. This is just the first step in encouraging more women to come forward and hold those responsible for sexual harassment accountable. – J.S.

Following my advocacy on the Senate Appropriations Committee, economic development funding for Northern New Hampshire was increased in a bipartisan government funding bill. This is a reversal of President Trump’s budget that proposed eliminating the Northern Border Regional Commission (NBRC), which administers this funding to Coos, Grafton, Carroll and Sullivan counties, as well as other areas of the Northeast. Recent Commission investments have brought important employment and infrastructure developments to these communities and provided funding for treatment and recovery services to help battle the opioid epidemic. I’ll continue to work across the aisle to ensure that this additional funding is signed into law and the NBRC can continue its important work.  – J.S.

We are hours away from the planned Senate Republican healthcare repeal vote, and yet they still haven’t disclosed what the final bill is that we’ll be voting on. Yes, you read that right. There have been no hearings. There’s no final bill. Yet, Republican leadership are voting anyway, jeopardizing the healthcare of millions of Americans. This is unacceptable and wrong! Republican leadership must listen to the American people and join with Democrats to make needed improvements to strengthen the Affordable Care Act, not recklessly repeal it. – J.S.

Senate Republicans just voted to move forward with healthcare repeal legislation without any input from the public. Republican leadership have not held any hearings on their healthcare repeal effort, nor have they even disclosed the final legislation that the Senate will be voting on in the coming days. This is deeply disturbing and not how a legislative body should function, particularly when it comes to legislation that impacts every American. I agree with Sen. McCain’s remarks on the Senate floor this afternoon: the Senate should work in a bipartisan fashion and in an open and transparent process to fix the problems in our healthcare system. I urge Republican leadership to come to the table and begin this important work now. – J.S.

This afternoon, I spoke on the Senate floor in opposition to the Senate Republican leadership’s healthcare repeal legislation. Their repeal of the Affordable Care Act would take health insurance from thousands of Granite Staters, is opposed by an overwhelming majority of stakeholder groups and negotiated entirely behind closed doors. It's time for Senate Republicans to listen to the American people and join with Democrats to make commonsense, bipartisan improvements to the Affordable Care Act, not repeal it. -- J.S.

Yesterday, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office determined that Senate Republican’s latest healthcare repeal plan would lead to 15 million people becoming uninsured, premium increases of 20% and the destabilization of the healthcare markets. Every plan Republican leadership has proposed would be devastating to the health and wellbeing of this country. It’s time for Senate Republicans to listen to the American people and join with Democrats to build on the strengths of the Affordable Care Act, not repeal it. – J.S.
Granite Staters continue to weigh in, as more than 8,800 are opposed to Senate Republican healthcare repeal efforts. It's time to listen to the American people. -- J.S.

Tonight, I’m very relieved that, for the time being, healthcare repeal has been set aside. Republican leadership, through a reckless and partisan process, came dangerously close to undermining healthcare for millions of Americans and tens of thousands of Granite Staters. The American people have made their voices heard and deserve credit for defeating this dangerous legislation. It's time for Republican leadership to finally abandon their attempts to repeal healthcare and begin working across the aisle to improve the Affordable Care Act. Healthcare is a life and death issue and it's time for Democrats and Republicans to come together and do the will of the American people.--J.S.

Today I joined Senator Hassan, Dean Kamen and Governor Sununu at the launch of Advanced Regenerative Manufacturing Institute's BiofabUSA facility. This new facility represents a critical investment in the future of the Granite State and will bring good jobs to New Hampshire. Congratulations to Dean, ARMI and everyone who helped advocate for this facility -- J.S.
My message to the thousands of Granite Staters who made their voices heard during the healthcare debate. -- J.S.

The Trump administration continues to disrupt the health insurance market by refusing to commit to making payments as required by the Affordable Care Act (ACA) that help Americans afford insurance coverage. Congress can end this artificial crisis by acting on legislation I have introduced that will provide certainty in the marketplace and permanently fund cost sharing reduction payments. The Marketplace Certainty Act will encourage health insurance companies to offer more affordable plans in a greater number of markets, improve competition and drive down costs for patients and families. I have already met with a bipartisan group of senators to discuss this legislation and a number of other solutions Congress can act on that will improve the ACA and create greater access to affordable care.  – J.S.
I have legislation to repeal the Trump administration’s Global Gag Rule. More here in my op-ed for Broadly. -- J.S.

I recently sat down with NBC News to discuss my legislation to protect the United States government from cyber threats. My amendment bars the use of Kaspersky Lab software at the federal level. Kaspersky Lab has come under increasing scrutiny for ties to the Russian government. This special report aired this weekend--you can watch it here:   http://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow/watch/russian-kaspersky-labs-faces-new-scrutiny-suspicion-1012640835507
Got this thank you note today from the Little Lobbyists. Made my day. They are so darn cute! - J.S.

This was a terrible idea and I’m glad the Department of Education has reversed course. Reducing the number of contracted student loan servicers to just one would have reduced the quality of assistance, made it harder for borrowers to manage their debt, and ultimately hurt students and their families. I was proud to recently sponsor bipartisan legislation that promotes, rather than reduces, competition among student loan servicers. – J.S.

Today I sat down with our summer class of interns during lunch, and it was great hearing about their ideas and ambitions. I’m glad they decided to get involved and I know our office has greatly appreciated their help. They all have bright futures ahead! – J.S.

I’m pleased the President signed the Russia sanctions legislation and gave the Kremlin the response it deserves for interfering in our democracy. I look forward to working with the administration to rigorously implement all parts of this law and demonstrate the United States’ unwillingness to turn a blind eye to attacks against our democratic processes and ideals. It’s important to note that the congressional reviews in this law are not ‘preferences’ as the President states in his signing statement, but rather are mandates passed by overwhelming majorities in both the House and Senate.   This law also takes appropriate steps to further sanction North Korea and Iran for their destabilizing actions. With these new sanctions, we are sending a resounding message that we are willing to exert bipartisan, American leadership, particularly in response to threats against our own country and against democracies worldwide. – J.S.

The President owes New Hampshire an apology and then should follow through on his promise to Granite Staters to help end the opioid crisis. It’s absolutely unacceptable for the President to be talking about New Hampshire in this way – it's a gross misrepresentation of New Hampshire and the epidemic. -- J.S.
Rather than disparaging the state of New Hampshire in calls with world leaders, it’s time for the President to follow through on his promise to Granite Staters.  -- J.S.
My thoughts and prayers are with Fatima, the captain of the Afghan FIRST robotics team, who just lost her father to a terrorist attack. -- J.S.
Great article in Elle Magazine on my friend and colleague, Senator Maggie Hassan. I’m grateful to have her as a partner in the Senate serving New Hampshire. – J.S

On CNBC, I talked about why the upcoming tax reform debate should be bipartisan and must make the tax code simpler for small businesses. Small businesses spend 2.5 billion hours complying with the tax code each year, and that's valuable time they could spend growing their businesses. -- J.S.

This morning I visited Seacoast Harley-Davidson, who are partnering with Great Bay Community College for a Motorcycle Maintenance and Repair certificate program. They are a terrific example of how the public and private sectors can collaborate in innovative ways to create jobs and opportunity across our state. Investing in workforce development is a win-win for our economy: a win for workers who want to fill the high-quality jobs that are available and a win for our small businesses looking for skilled talent. – J.S.

Today I met with Secretary of Veterans Affairs David Shulkin, staff at the Manchester VA, and veterans who receive care at the Manchester VA. While many veterans receive quality care from the Manchester VA, there’s much work to be done to ensure accountability for substandard services. I applaud the courageous whistleblowers who bravely spoke out on behalf of patients at the Manchester VA and am glad they had the opportunity to speak directly with Secretary Shulkin. It’s so important that the VA rebuild trust with the veteran community by consistently delivering the quality care they deserve in a timely fashion. Secretary Shulkin’s presence today, and his attentiveness to care delivery issues at the Manchester VA, gives me hope that the VA will address any shortfalls at this facility. New funding for a coordinated care center is a very positive step in the right direction. And I’m very pleased that funding to repair water damage is being quickly provided. I also appreciate Secretary Shulkin’s commitment to establish a task force that will examine providing New Hampshire’s veterans with the full range of care services. All of New Hampshire’s veterans deserve high quality, convenient, accessible health care and I will continue to work with Secretary Shulkin, the VA and the delegation until we achieve that goal. -- J.S.

The Trump administration can act immediately to provide healthcare marketplace stability, and I welcome Governor Sununu’s letter to President Trump calling on him to do so. By refusing to implement key provisions of the Affordable Care Act, the Trump administration has caused unnecessary chaos in New Hampshire’s healthcare marketplace. As Governor Sununu’s letter points out, this uncertainty has caused insurers to raise premiums and even leave ACA marketplaces altogether. I’m very encouraged that there’s growing bipartisan support for measures to stabilize healthcare marketplaces in this country. In the Senate, I’ll continue to urge action on my legislation that would stabilize healthcare marketplaces and provide more support for Americans to afford healthcare coverage. Healthcare is a life and death issue and it's time for the President to do the will of the American people. -- J.S.

I applaud the President’s announcement that he will declare the opioid epidemic a national emergency. It’s long past time for the federal government to aggressively tackle this crisis. As part of this emergency declaration, I urge the President to implement the other sound recommendations proposed by his opioid commission and work with Congress to pass legislation that provides first responders and treatment providers the emergency resources they desperately need. The President also needs to abandon his efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act which would take away life-saving substance misuse treatment. There’s broad bipartisan agreement that much more needs to be done to end this epidemic that’s taking a life every day in New Hampshire and tens of thousands of lives every year across the country. -- J.S.

Yesterday I visited the National Criminal Justice Training Center (NCJTC) in Durham to receive an update on their operations, including the training being done for the Internet Crimes Against Children (ICAC) Task Force Program. It’s critical that the NJCTC continues to receive funding for the training and programs they provide to law enforcement and prosecutorial agencies. In my role as the lead Democrat on the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, Science, I’ll work to ensure resources are available for NCJTC and other centers across the country that conduct this important work. – J.S.

There is no debate, Neo-Nazis and white supremacists are on the wrong side. It's disgraceful for President Trump to suggest otherwise. There is no room for hatred, racism and violence in America. -- J.S.

Yesterday, I was able to visit Jackson Estuarine Lab and took a boat ride out on the Great Bay to learn more about the research and work the Sea Grant program is doing. It's critical we continue to fund this program and support conservation efforts in the Great Bay. -- J.S.

This afternoon I visited PAK solutions in Lancaster, a manufacturing company that specializes in tamper-proof bags. I was able to meet with many of the employees and the members of their new leadership team, who are making investments in this growing North County business. New Hampshire is a small business state, and I'll continue to advocate for small businesses in my role as lead Democrat on the Small Business & Entrepreneurship Committee. -- J.S.

Today I met with local business, education and workforce training leaders about preparing New Hampshire workers and businesses to be competitive in the 21st-century economy. Thank you to our representatives from Graphicast, Badger Balm, the Community College System of New Hampshire, Omni Mt. Washington Resort and the New Hampshire Job Corps for joining me to discuss solutions to the challenges we face in retraining and expanding our workforce. -- J.S.

Today I visited Valley Regional Healthcare in Claremont, where I met with CEO Peter Wright and hospital staff to discuss the importance of finding bipartisan fixes to the Affordable Care Act. I’ve already introduced legislation, the Marketplace Certainty Act, which would permanently appropriate cost-sharing reduction payments and expand healthcare eligibility to more hard-working Americans who need help affording their premiums. While we're pleased that the Senate HELP Committee has scheduled hearings in September to discuss stabilizing the healthcare market, it’s critical that the Trump administration commits to funding cost-sharing reduction payments beyond August. I’ll continue to work across the aisle to ensure more Granite Staters have access to affordable, quality healthcare. – J.S.

There are new reports that the White House plans to soon provide the Pentagon with guidance on implementation for a ban prohibiting transgender Americans from serving in the US military. The President’s actions to ban transgender Americans from serving their country is disgraceful. There are thousands of transgender Americans putting their lives on the line every day to defend our nation, people and liberty. Imposing a national defense policy that discriminates against American service members based on their gender identity violates their civil rights, undermines our military readiness and puts those affected by the ban, as well as their commanders, in a terrible position. As a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, I oppose this egregious policy and will work with my colleagues in Congress to push back on the Administration’s decision so we can protect all transgender service members proudly serving our nation.” -- J.S.

I wrote a letter with Senator Maggie Hassan and Congresswoman Carol Shea-Porter to the U.S. Air Force requesting an update on efforts to treat water supplies contaminated with perfluorinated chemicals (PFCs) at Pease. I’ve heard from thousands of Seacoast families who are worried about the safety of their drinking water and they deserve answers. I’ll continue to stand beside the Pease community to address this critical health issue. – J.S.

Reports that the President is considering ending the Deferred Action  for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) Program are devastating. We are talking about more than half a million young people who will be torn away from their families. These are law-abiding individuals who work, go to school and are integral members of our community. For most, this is the only home they have ever known. Ending the DACA program is both heartless and harmful to the stability of our communities and workforce. -- J.S.

The President's decision to ban transgender service members is shameful‎ and un-American. As a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, I'll fight to protect our transgender service members honorably serving our country. -- J.S.

My thoughts are with victims’ loved ones and those impacted by the horrific devastation in Texas. New Hampshire is with you. Thank you to Lloyd and the other Red Cross workers across New England and throughout the country who are helping residents in Texas. -- J.S.

Last week, I had the opportunity to visit Milpower Source in Belmont. Milpower Source is a premier small business manufacturer that not only makes valuable contributions to our Granite State economy, but also continues our state’s long tradition of supporting our national defense. New Hampshire is a small business state, and it’s crucial that we continue to support small businesses like Milpower Source with workforce development programs. Read more about my visit in the Laconia Daily Sun. -- J.S.

Do you or someone you know need help accessing a federal agency? My office is here to help. On Friday, September 1st, my staff will hold office hours at the Peterborough Community Center from 10am to 11am. If you have any additional questions, please call 603-647-7500. -- J.S.

I’m pleased that federal health officials have indicated that a national health study on perfluorinated chemicals (PFCs) would start with a pilot study at Pease. New Hampshire and Seacoast families deserve peace of mind, and it’s critical that Congress acts on my legislation to fund this health study for drinking water systems. I’ll continue to work across the aisle to make sure this happens. – J.S.

I thank the NH AFL-CIO for fighting for middle-class jobs across the Granite State and working to ensure that hard-working Americans get their fair share. As we continue to rebuild our economy, it is critical we support strong unions.  -- J.S.

Secretary DeVos's decision to undo the schools directive on sexual assault is both shameful and dangerous. There’s no reason to rescind this guidance for sexual assault survivors, like Chessy Prout. Congrats to Victoria Arlen on being selected to compete on the next season of Dancing with the Stars! This is what Senators Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan had to say after the latest attempt by Kris Kobach, Vice Chairman of President Trump's voting commission, to mislead the public:   "It has been clear since its inception that President Trump's voting commission is an attempt to grossly mislead voters and lay the groundwork for broad-scale, politically motivated voter suppression. Today’s voting commission hearing should have every Granite State voter worried. Recommendations that were put forward today ran the gamut from thumbprints on photo IDs to background checks at the polls, as well as baseless assertions that same-day registration enables voter fraud. Perpetuating falsehoods about voter fraud in New Hampshire risks jeopardizing our first-in-the nation presidential primary.    And while U.S. intelligence agencies have no doubt that Russia interfered in our elections to undermine faith in our democracy, there was no substantive discussion of this by the commission. Today I announced my support for the Medicare For All Act which was introduced by Senator Bernie Sanders. I believe that healthcare should be a fundamental right in this country. Too many Granite Staters continue to struggle to access quality affordable healthcare. I know that in a Republican-controlled Congress this legislation will not pass in the near term, but I believe this bill puts pressure on Congress to think big when it comes to providing the healthcare that all Americans need and deserve. The immediate task at hand for Congress is to stabilize the current healthcare marketplace and find bipartisan means to drive down costs. I am encouraged by recent bipartisan healthcare hearings and I’m optimistic that Congress will soon act to pass bipartisan legislation that makes necessary adjustments to the Affordable Care Act, including my proposal to continue providing cost-sharing support for working families. – J.S.

Edith Windsor was a champion of the LGBT community whose activism led the Supreme Court to grant same-sex married couples equal recognition and rights under federal law. She devoted her life to advocating for equality, freedom and love for all. Her legacy will continue to live on. – J.S.

There are reports that Health and Human Services (HHS) Secretary Tom Price is using private jets for official travel. Commercial transportation could have easily accommodated the travel cited in this report, particularly his trips to New Hampshire and Philadelphia. Congratulations to the Portsmouth Police Department on receiving $264K for its National Internet Crimes Against Children (ICAC) Task Force Program. The Graham-Cassidy healthcare repeal bill rolls back protections for pre-existing conditions. It’s disingenuous to suggest otherwise. -- J.S.

I’m deeply disappointed by Secretary DeVos’s decision to roll back measures that were put in place to protect students and increase accountability at college campuses across the country. Repealing this policy undermines efforts to combat sexual assault and creates confusion for universities, including those in New Hampshire, that have taken steps to implement recommendations and policies based on this guidance. The decision to rescind this campus sexual assault policy lacked transparency and critical input from stakeholders. Unraveling these guidelines without feedback or discussion doesn’t help further our goal of getting justice for victims, which has been and must remain our top priority. -- J.S.

This morning, I joined Senator Hassan at Elliot Hospital to speak out against the Graham-Cassidy healthcare repeal bill, which would be absolutely devastating for New Hampshire families. This legislation makes profound cuts to Medicaid and healthcare coverage, and guts protections for pre-existing conditions. Overall, this legislation would strip New Hampshire of $410 million in federal support for healthcare coverage under Medicaid and by one estimate, New Hampshire would lose $3 billion in healthcare funding over the next ten years. The AARP estimates that this legislation will increase out-of-pocket costs for seniors making $25,000 annually by $11,600 per year due to the elimination of tax credits, cost-sharing reduction subsidies and age-rating limits! That’s just unconscionable.  It’s important to note that by rushing to pass Graham-Cassidy, Republican leadership pulled the plug on bipartisan efforts to fix current problems in our healthcare system. It’s imperative that Congress restart bipartisan negotiations to stabilize the healthcare marketplace and lower costs for Granite State families. – J.S.
I had a fun time at the NASCAR ISM Connect 300 at New Hampshire Motor Speedway on Sunday. Great to meet Danica Patrick and Dale Earnhardt Jr.! -- J.S.

Last night, President Trump announced a new travel ban that once again overwhelmingly targets Muslim immigrants from Muslim-majority nations. This new ban doubles down on his misguided policy of targeting immigrants and other travelers from Muslim-majority nations. To shore up our borders and improve our national defense, we need policies rooted in intelligence and security – not division and fear. Just like the previous orders, this ban does not reflect our country’s values and only makes us less safe by reinforcing terrorist propaganda and recruitment. Immigrants make up the fabric of this country, and they continue to enrich our communities and strengthen our economy. America must remain open and continue to be a refuge for those seeking a better life. – J.S.

I had the opportunity to meet with Malala, the youngest Nobel Laureate in history and co-founder of the Malala Fund. Malala’s dedication to girls’ education continues to be an inspiration to the world. It was a pleasure to meet and thank her for her important work. We know that girls’ education is directly related to healthy communities, successful economies and secure nations. I’ll continue to urge Congress to work to ensure every young girl around the globe is given the opportunity to reach their full potential.  – J.S.

It’s undeniable that Medicaid has helped Ashley Hurteau and thousands of others in New Hampshire get the treatment they need for substance use disorders. I’ll continue to stand against any legislation that undermines New Hampshire’s efforts to fight the opioid epidemic and takes away care from those who need it most. -- J.S.

The vote has been canceled on the Graham-Cassidy healthcare repeal bill. Thank you to all who spoke out against this disastrous legislation! I’ll continue to stand against legislation that would be disastrous to the health and wellbeing of New Hampshire and urge bipartisan cooperation to stabilize healthcare marketplaces and lower costs. – J.S.

This development should serve as a stark warning, not just to the federal government, but to states, local governments, and the American public, of the serious dangers of using Kaspersky software. The Trump administration just announced the repeal of the birth control mandate included in the Affordable Care Act (ACA). This administration’s obsession with rolling back women’s reproductive rights and access to care is dangerous and reflects a shallow understanding of women’s health. This order will undoubtedly increase unwanted pregnancies and abortions, at a time when both are at an all-time low. I will continue to fight for women’s access to coverage for preventative services, including birth control, and will oppose any effort that infringes on, or compromises, their reproductive freedom. I urge the President to consult health experts and reverse this ill-considered policy shift and work with Democrats to improve access to healthcare, which includes reproductive health services. -- J.S.

Throughout her career, Congressomwan Carol Shea-Porter has been a stalwart defender and champion of New Hampshire. New Hampshire's first district has been well served by her tireless devotion to the middle class and the most vulnerable in our society. As the first woman to be elected to New Hampshire's federal delegation, she's a trail blazer in her own right, who has been a fearless advocate for women's equality. I look forward to working with her through the remainder of her term, and to seeing what the future brings. -- J.S.

Today my bipartisan bill, the Women, Peace and Security Act, was signed into law by the President. We need female representation on the world stage that accurately reflects the makeup of communities directly impacted by violence and armed conflict. I’m proud that this bipartisan effort will sustain the U.S. commitment to promoting greater female representation in conflict resolution and peacebuilding. Reinforcing these priorities by statute will help to ensure our country continues to implement the United Nations Security Council Resolution on the role of women in peace and security by training American diplomats, military personnel and development workers on these important issues, and by requiring the President to produce a strategy to make this a U.S. foreign policy priority. -- J.S.

The Trump administration’s decision to roll back the Clean Power Plan continues a dangerous agenda that will harm the environment and public health. We owe it to future generations to build on the Clean Power Plan and incentivize energy efficiency and the transition to cleaner, renewable forms of energy. By beginning efforts to roll back this critical rule, the Trump administration is ignoring the devastating effects of climate change and the glaring action needed to combat the environmental threats we face here and around the globe. Rising temperatures interrupt New Hampshire’s fall foliage season and maple syrup production, directly impeding our business and tourism sectors, and elevated sea levels put the homes and livelihoods of our Seacoast families at risk. I urge the President to consult with scientists and environmental experts, and to reconsider this decision, which, if implemented, will have very real consequences for the future of our country and planet. -- J.S.

The Trump administration announced that it will end cost-sharing reduction payments, which help middle-income to low-income Americans afford health insurance.The American people made it very clear that they didn’t want healthcare repeal, yet President Trump is forcing it on them anyway through sabotage. Ending cost-sharing reduction payments is part of a concerted effort by this administration to undermine the Affordable Care Act, and will sow further chaos in healthcare marketplaces. Families in New Hampshire and across the country are going to experience drastic cost increases and loss of coverage because of President Trump’s many actions to erode healthcare reform in this country. It’s absolutely critical that Congress act to stabilize the insurance marketplace and lower costs, and I will continue to work across the aisle to fix this manufactured crisis. -- J.S.

The Seacoast Indonesian community are our friends and neighbors, and they should be allowed to stay in New Hampshire. Deporting these families is senseless and inhumane. I’m continuing to urge the Trump administration to reverse course before it's too late. – J.S.

Senator Hassan and I joined Andrea Mitchell this afternoon to discuss the President’s announcement on the opioid epidemic. Busy day! I’ll continue to support programs like GEAR UP, Upward Bound, TRIO and the New Hampshire Scholars Initiative that have an amazing track record of helping students prepare, attend, and graduate college. It’s important that the President and his administration understand that there’s bipartisan support for keeping the Seacoast Indonesian families intact and in New Hampshire. I’ll continue to urge the administration and immigration officials to exercise commonsense discretion and restraint in dealing with this community, including implementing enforcement policies that reflect our nation’s humanitarian values and ideals. – J.S.

I applaud the Court's decision to block this un-American policy. Discriminating against American service members based on their gender identity violates their civil rights, undermines our military readiness and puts those affected by the ban, as well as their commanders, in a terrible position. There are thousands of transgender Americans putting their lives on the line every day to defend our nation, people and liberty, and they should be celebrated, not punished. – J.S.

Open enrollment runs from November 1st to December 15th. I’ll continue to support bipartisan measures to restore funding for enrollment ads and outreach, lower premiums, and strengthen key elements of the law. In the meantime, every Granite Stater can also play a role by helping us spread the word to our friends and neighbors that quality health coverage under the ACA is available to all who need it. To learn more about open enrollment for 2018 health insurance plans and apply online, visit https://www.healthcare.gov/get-coverage/. -- J.S.

The Trump administration just announced that it will not revise the formula that determines state opioid funding. The current formula underfunds New Hampshire because it considers state population size, rather than rate of overdose death, as a significant factor. This is a tremendously disappointing decision. New Hampshire has the second highest opioid overdose death rate in the country and is experiencing the worst public health crisis in its history. The Trump administration had an opportunity to prioritize communities that are most desperate for resources. In dozens of visits to New Hampshire during the campaign, President Trump promised significant support to end this epidemic, and we’re still waiting for meaningful follow through. I strongly urge President Trump and his administration to reconsider this decision and begin working with Congress to provide additional resources to New Hampshire and other areas of the country that are most affected by this epidemic. Without a significant investment, this epidemic will continue to expand and take lives at ever-alarming rates. – J.S.

Over the weekend, another community was devastated by gun violence. I know I speak for all Granite Staters when I say that we stand with people in Sutherland Springs, Texas as they deal with the heartbreaking loss of so many family and community members. As more of these horrific incidents occur around the country, it’s easy to grow numb and complacent, but it’s so important that we not accept this violence as normal and continue to urge action to prevent the next tragedy.  Today, I helped introduce bipartisan legislation to keep guns out of the wrong hands. The mass murderer in Sutherland Springs was able to purchase firearms because of a loophole that kept his record of domestic violence from appearing in his background check. Had this information been provided by the military, the sale could not have legally gone through. My legislation gets rid of that loophole by requiring the Armed Services to report misdemeanors of domestic violence so that they appear in the federal background check system.   We know that domestic violence is a red flag for further violence. More than 55% of all female homicides are the victims of their intimate partners. I find that statistic just staggering. Congress urgently needs to take steps to ensure violent abusers are barred from purchasing guns. It’s my hope that we can build on the bipartisan support my legislation already has and pass it in Congress, and look at other ways to protect the public from senseless violence.   The vast majority of Granite Staters agree that we need sensible gun laws in place that don’t infringe on the rights of responsible gun owners. Despite Republican leadership’s resistance to this commonsense approach, I’m not going accept the status quo -- I’m going to continue to reach across the aisle until Congress takes meaningful action to prevent gun violence. -- J.S.

I joined a bipartisan group of Senators to introduce the Fix NICS Act to ensure federal and state authorities comply with existing law and accurately report relevant criminal history records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS).  The shooting in Sutherland Springs tragically demonstrated woeful inadequacies in our federal background check system. We urgently need to bolster our efforts to keep guns out of the wrong hands by making sure criminal history in the federal background check system is comprehensive and updated in a timely fashion. Our legislation is the product of good faith bipartisan discussions and I hope Congress can quickly consider this legislation and send it to the President’s desk. The American people have waited for far too long for bipartisan progress to address gun violence. -- J.S.

We need to simplify our tax code, help small businesses and deliver real relief to the middle class. The GOP tax bill achieves none of that. Here’s why I’m opposed:  •The GOP tax bill will force Granite State families and millions more across the nation who make less than $75K a year to pay MORE in taxes by 2027.   •The GOP tax bill again tries to repeal parts of Obamacare which will raise healthcare costs. The American public have already made their voices loud and clear that they don’t want their healthcare repealed.   •Seniors also get hurt – the GOP tax bill will result in a $25 billion cut to Medicare. Seniors have paid into this program their entire lives. They deserve better.  •College graduates lose out – they’re no longer able to deduct interest on student loans. New Hampshire has one of the highest student loan burdens in the country. The GOP tax bill will make it worse.   •Work-study students at colleges and universities will see a steep tax increase which will make college even more unaffordable and discourage higher learning.   •Under the GOP tax bill, homeowners in New Hampshire lose the ability to deduct property taxes – a real blow to middle-class families.   All this to pass permanent tax cuts for corporations by adding $1.5 trillion to our national debt. We need a tax bill that’s fiscally responsible, helps grow our economy and prioritizes the middle class. This is NOT it. -- J.S.

I’ve been reviewing the Republican tax bill and I’ve got many concerns. Fundamentally, this just isn’t tax reform and that’s very disappointing. As every tax filer knows, we need to simplify the tax code. We also need to give a real tax break to the middle class and small businesses. Here’s what the Republican tax bill does instead:   • Most families who make less than $75,000 a year will pay more in taxes by 2027. And according to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, by 2019, Americans earning less than $30,000 a year would be worse off. By 2021, Americans earning $40,000 or less would be at a net loss.   • This bill would lead to $25 billion in cuts from Medicare harming seniors.   • It repeals parts of Obamacare which will raise healthcare costs and leave more Americans uninsured. The American people have said over and over that they’re strongly opposed to repealing healthcare, yet this bill is another backdoor attempt to undo the healthcare law.   • It prevents homeowners in New Hampshire from deducting property taxes – a real blow to middle-class families.  • Work-study students at colleges and universities would see a steep tax increase which will make college even more unaffordable and discourage higher learning.  • The House version of the bill no longer allows college students and graduates to deduct student loan interest. New Hampshire has the highest student loan burden per capita in the country and this provision would make it worse.  Not everyone does poorly in this bill: big corporations and the wealthy get a massive, permanent tax break which is paid for by the middle class and adding $1.5 trillion to the national debt. Talk about misplaced priorities. And by one estimate, President Trump himself could benefit by as much as $1 billion under this plan.   This bill is a real missed opportunity. Again, Congress should be prioritizing bipartisan reform that delivers real relief to Granite Staters. As this debate continues, I’ll be urging Congress to reverse course and put the middle class first. -- J.S.

Congress must not be resistant to the awareness of sexual harassment and accountability that is sweeping the country. Those who experience sexual harassment on Capitol Hill face a daunting struggle to reach any semblance of justice and often have egregious restrictions that prevent them from speaking out. It’s also galling that the taxpayer, rather than the perpetrator, is on the hook for paying settlements. This must change. Today, I joined with a bipartisan group of senators, led by Senators Kirsten Gillibrand and Ted Cruz, to introduce legislation to make long overdue reforms to how Congress addresses sexual harassment claims. Here’s what the Congressional Harassment Reform Act would do:   •Eliminate forced mediation and allows victims to speak publicly about their case;  •Establish additional victim protections and empowers them with the choice of how to resolve their complaint;   •Require that Members of Congress be personally liable for harassment settlements; •Require that all settlements be publicly disclosed unless the victim chooses to keep them private; •And extend protections to interns and fellows.   I’m urging Congressional leadership to quickly begin consideration of this important bill because we need accountability in the halls of Congress. This is an area where we can clearly make bipartisan progress and help change the culture around sexual harassment. -- J.S.

Late last night, Republican leadership called a vote on the final version of their tax bill. Here's why I voted against it. This tax bill asks middle-class families to foot the bill for massive tax breaks for the wealthy and large corporations—that’s just unacceptable. Further, adding $1.5 trillion to the national debt to pay for these tax cuts will undermine our ability to address real challenges facing the middle class and small businesses. Instead, this bill doesn’t remotely resemble real tax reform and is an enormous missed opportunity. Going forward, Congress must do better and allow the public into the legislative process, particularly for legislation that touches the lives of all Americans. --J.S.

This new data confirms what we already know is happening in communities across our state. Every overdose death reflected in this report is a life taken far too soon, a family devastated, and a community in mourning. This report should serve as a timely reminder that, as Congress works on government funding legislation, additional resources should be included to assist treatment providers and first responders in New Hampshire and around the country. The Trump administration has consistently promised federal support to tackle this epidemic, but we still don’t have a federal response providing real, sustained resources that is even close to matching the severity of this crisis. -- J.S.

I spoke on the Senate floor this afternoon about Congressional Republican leadership’s dangerous and callous decision to prioritize partisan politics over the needs of the middle class. The Republican tax bill repeals a critical part of our healthcare law, which will result in 13 million fewer Americans having health coverage. Additionally, this bill missed an important opportunity to address our nation’s severe opioid epidemic. Today we learned that 63,000 people died from overdoses in 2016. American families deserve a Senate that values bipartisanship, cooperation and compromise in the service of all Americans, not just our largest corporations and the wealthiest in this country. – J.S.
